business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston. Has the minister sought a briefing from his department on the veracity or otherwise of the claims of the heads of two auditing companies, Consulcom and Billbusters, that Telstra derived more than $800 million of its profit last year from overcharging customer accounts? Has the minister sought a report from Telstra? Does the minister consider there is any substance to these claims? If so, what action does he propose to take?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I did see the reports. I also saw a strenuous denial by a spokesman for Telstra. They are, of course, matters of concern to the government, particularly the quantum alleged, and we would certainly expect the matters to be properly investigated by the communications authority, the ACCC, or even the TIO. There are plenty of people who have direct responsibility for aspects of charging and billing and we would expect them to be pursuing those matters.

answer.para: Certainly there is already an industry code of practice in place in relation to the accuracy and timeliness of charging and billing, and the communications authority has the power to direct any non-complying carriage service provider to comply with the code. The TIO is also able to investigate and make determinations on complaints about overcharging of certain services, including standard telephone services provided to residential and small business users, and public mobile services.

The ACCC has a general mandate to protect consumers and considerable powers to investigate allegations of anti-competitive conduct. I understand that Telstra has already written to the ACCC claiming that the allegations constitute misleading and deceptive conduct. There is clearly an area of dispute, but it is not one that needs to be resolved by the government at this point in time or that requires more than an expression of concern; from that will flow all the necessary and proper inquiries.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, in view of your concern—but it was not clear whether you had sought information or had asked the ACCC or any other regulatory body to investigate the claim and provide you with information, or whether as minister you had referred it to any of those bodies for investigation—are you aware that Mr Paul Morris, the head of Consulcom, has provided details of overcharges on 65 businesses his company assessed? Is the minister aware that Consulcom assessed an average $23,000 overcharge for each business and that billing errors ranged from tens of dollars for small operations to $625,980 for Woolworths? Again, Minister, in view of the seriousness of these charges, can you confirm that you have actually sought information or asked the relevant regulatory agencies that you mentioned to investigate these very serious claims?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —All Senator Schacht has done really is to repeat the substance of the allegations, and as I have said, on the face of it, a substantial sum of money is involved. These are matters of concern.
—Have you raised them with the relevant authorities?

—I have not gone out of my way to make specific inquiries, but certainly I gave a press interview at the time indicating that I wanted the matters to be looked at by all the relevant authorities. My understanding from the department is that that is already occurring. Indeed, as I have already said to you, Telstra hotly contests these allegations to the point of alleging bad faith on the part of at least one of those who have conducted the survey.
—They always do! They always do.

interjection.para: Senator Schacht interjecting—

talk.start.para: —We know where your prejudices are coming from. I would have thought that you would be prepared to await the outcome of those various inquiries and then pass judgment, and not do what silly old Senator Carr seems to think is the appropriate approach—that is, bagging Telstra every time he gets half a chance.

answer.para: In fact, you ought to concentrate a bit more on getting those branch stacking allegations clarified. I can understand why you do not want to, because you would be terrified if they actually adopted a merit based preselection process. You would have no hope at all. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Tomorrow marks the start of National Reconciliation Week. Will the minister outline the government's approach to the important issue of national reconciliation and how all Australians can participate in achieving genuine reconciliation?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Heffernan for the question and I acknowledge his interest in Aboriginal affairs. I would like to take this opportunity to remind the Senate that tomorrow is the start of National Reconciliation Week. This is an important week for all of us. It is an opportunity for all Australians to come together to address the many disadvantages faced by many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. We need to strive for equality of opportunity for all Australians.

answer.para: This government has tackled the hard issues head-on. We have taken a practical and responsible approach to indigenous affairs, and we are making a difference, but there is more work to be done. We are taking a significantly different approach from that of the previous government. Instead of throwing bucketfuls of money at problems, we are ensuring accountability and measured outcomes. We sent the army into communities which desperately required urgent action. These were communities which lacked basic essentials. Now they are getting clean drinking water, housing, health care, sewage treat ment, roads and airstrips. This initiative is also creating practical improvements in the lives of many of this nation's most disadvantaged by ensuring that skills in construction and ongoing maintenance are transferred to community members.

Australians, indigenous and non-indigenous, have a right to be disappointed by the lack of improvement in the lives of Aboriginal people over the last 13 years under Labor. It is a source of frustration for all of us and has damaged the reconciliation process. Reconciliation needs to begin at the grassroots level—on the street, in the supermarket aisle, at the local football club. We can all play a part, and I urge all Australians to get involved. Today is National Sorry Day. Sorry Day is a private event organised by the council for reconciliation—
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Herron, there is far too much noise in the chamber and your voice can scarcely be heard.
—He's embarrassed!

—Those on the other side are embarrassed for the 13 years of neglect and what they have produced. Today is National Sorry Day. Sorry Day is a private event, organised by the council for reconciliation and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

answer.para: I welcome the Prime Minister's announcement today that public donations to the stolen children's support fund will be made tax deductible. The government will amend the income tax law to allow deductions for donations of $2 or more to assist in providing counselling, education and monitoring of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who were separated from their families.

The government has already provided a $63 million package to address the recommendations of the Bringing them home report. This includes practical measures to assist in family reunion and counselling. As I have stated many times already, the Prime Minister and I deeply regret the past injustices which were committed against Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Acknowledging that European settlement had tragic consequences is part of the healing process.

This event, National Sorry Day, should not be allowed to turn people off reconciliation. People have expressed to me their concern about the concept of a sorry day; others have said they just cannot relate to it. There is division in the community about a formal apology. People should not be made to feel guilty for something that they had no direct part in. It is up to individuals to decide whether or not they want to say sorry. I have already expressed my regret for the past policies of separation but that does not seem to be recognised by the other side.

We need to work on uniting the community, uniting all Australians. Reconciliation Week is an opportunity for that. The seed must be planted in the hearts and minds of ordinary Australians. It is not something the government can legislate for. Reconciliation must grow upwards from the community.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Has the minister's attention been drawn to growing criticisms of his appointment of Kerry Blackman to the augmented review panel examining redistributed boundaries for ATSIC's Rockhampton and Roma regional councils? Is it a fact that the Roma Regional Council has written complaining about Mr Blackman's appointment? Can the minister confirm that ATSIC's Rockhampton Chairman, David Wragge, has written to him to express his concerns about Mr Blackman's appointment and to point out Mr Blackman's removal as an ATSIC councillor in 1994, in controversial circumstances, for breaching ATSIC guidelines? Given Mr Blackman's personal and controversial involvement in ATSIC politics in the region, why does the minister consider him to be an appropriate person to conduct such a sensitive political task as an electoral boundary review?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I can confirm the structure of the remarks made by Senator Reynolds. It is true that I have appointed Mr Kerry Blackman, an outstanding Australian and a member of the reconciliation council. I have questioned him about the allegations made. He denies them completely. It is interesting that auditors have been put in to some of the organisations that are critical of him. I have received a letter from Mr Wragge, as mentioned. I suggest that Senator Reynolds should hold off until she sees the outcome of those investigations, particularly other material that will come out in the course of events, before she supports allegations which will, I expect, turn out to be baseless.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, given the sensitivity of this electoral review and the circumstances I outlined, precisely which qualities, experience or skills do you believe that Mr Blackman can bring to this sensitive task?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Mr Blackman was an ATSIC commissioner at one stage, he is a very active businessman in the community, and he is knowledgeable in electoral affairs. I am very happy to back him in his judgment against those of his opponents, as I understand it at the moment. We will all have wait to see the outcome of investigations before seeing whether there is any validity that can be attached to allegations made about him.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice, Senator Vanstone. As a result of the return of the Skase passport to Australia, Mr Skase has attempted to gain a passport from the Republic of Seychelles. What steps has the government taken to prevent Mr Skase from obtaining a passport from a third country? How do the actions of the coalition government in chasing Mr Skase compare with those of the former Labor government?
—I thank Senator Coonan for the question. Yesterday in the Senate, I made it clear that the government had secured the return of Mr Skase's cancelled Australian passport.
—Which has never been used!

—Despite the claims of the opposition, supported by Senator Bolkus saying, `Which has never been used'—he clearly does not understand the variety of uses of a passport—it has presented difficulties for Skase. He has attempted to obtain a passport from the Republic of Seychelles. The government has urged the Seychelles not to issue a passport or other document for travel to Mr Skase. Mr Downer has instructed his department to urge foreign governments not to issue Mr Skase with a passport. Skase's efforts to obtain a Seychelles passport demonstrate the value of cancelling his passport.

answer.para: The question that needs to be asked is this: why didn't Labor's Minister for Foreign Affairs, now Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Gareth Evans, take that action himself? Why did Gareth Evans allow Skase to be reissued with a passport? Why did he not cancel Mr Skase's passport? Labor issued Skase with a 10-year passport. Gareth Evans could have issued Mr Skase with a passport for a period of less than 10 years; he could have issued him with a three-year passport; he could have issued him with a one-way travel document back to Australia.

Senator Evans allowed the issuing of the passport and subsequently failed to cancel the passport when the Department of Foreign Affairs had put a special alert on his passport. This was not a case of just a passport coming in out of the blue; there was a special tag on this passport and the tag said, `Do not reissue unless you go back to Canberra.' I am advised that the particular file had an annotation on it with an instruction that then Minister Evans be notified in the event that Skase applied for a passport.

So now the question needs to be asked: what did then Minister Evans do when he was presumably notified that Mr Skase was seeking a passport? I understand that Canberra was notified on 7 July 1993 and that he actually applied on Friday the 9th. Then we had the weekend—and people in the gallery might like to think about this: if you apply for a passport on Friday, do you reckon you normally get told on the Saturday that you can have it?
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You wouldn't expect to get it on the Saturday or the Sunday, and a normal citizen wouldn't expect to get it on the Monday or Tuesday—
—You get the booby prize.
—There are far too many interventions.

—Guess what Madam President? On the Tuesday, after hardly any consideration, Canberra notified Madrid that Skase could be issued with a new passport that took him up to the year 2003. Mr Skase needs to stay in Spain only until 2002 to possibly qualify for Spanish citizenship. So the dilatoriness, the laziness and the incompetence of the previous Minister for Foreign Affairs, who stood in this place lecturing us on our incompetence, inflating his own intelligence and ego—
—Not one stamp in five years.
—Senator Bolkus, cease interjecting.

—It is that incompetence, dilatoriness, laziness and complete hopelessness that gave Skase a passport that would entitle him to stay in Spain, in all other circumstances, until the year 2003. He might become qualified for citizenship in 2002 and if this government had not acted to cancel his passport, that might have happened.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can the minister outline what, if any, action Employment National has undertaken to assist people with disabilities to gain access to their services? Can the minister explain why Employment National has set up an office in Bathurst on the first floor of a building with no lift or other apparent means of assisting people with disabilities to access the office? How many other Employment National offices are similarly situated?

—I am not aware of the situation of the Bathurst office but I can say that there are facilities for disadvantaged people to make inquiries about jobs. That can be done through any Centrelink office, not necessarily Employment National. There are another 309 job providers that they can make a choice from. So it not only Employment National's office they can go to. What these people have available to them—

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Ellison—
—is another 309 organisations.

—Senator Ellison, I am trying to ask you to resume your seat. The level of interjection is so high that when I call a senator he cannot hear. Senators at the other end of the chamber would not be able to hear and the level of noise in the vicinity of the chair is outrageous.

interjection.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Carr, I am warning you that if you keep shouting after I have spoken to you, I will take action.

—What I can say is that in November last year it was announced that, as from 1 May this year, Centrelink would have a new referral process which would assist job seekers with disabilities. That is primarily the substance of the question from Senator West to me. What we are talking about is making it easier for those people with disabilities to seek jobs. As for that particular instance in Bathurst I am not aware of that but that is not the only office that job seekers have to go to. As I said, there are another 309 organisations that they can choose from. Centrelink has improved its referral process and its facilities for disabled people.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the government taken any action to ensure that the other 309 contracted job agencies are siting their offices in locations that can be accessed by people with disabilities?

—In the contract with the job providers there is a code of conduct which they agree to. One item is the provision of such services. If Senator West is aware of any problems, she should bring them to the notice of the government and we will have a look at it.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, I refer you to the resignation statement today by former Liberal MP Tony Smith, the third backbencher in as many months to quit the Liberal government, bringing to six—
—Order! Senators on my right will cease interjecting—
—What about your leader?
—Senator Abetz and Senator Ferguson will cease interjecting.

—This brings to six the number of ex-Liberals sitting in the House of Representatives. Minister, do you agree with Mr Smith that the government plans to dump the GST and its tax package on the electorate without proper debate? Can you assure the Senate that Mr Smith's concern is ill-founded and that, indeed, your tax package will not be dumped on us without providing the Australian people with proper time to consider it? In other words, how far out from the election are you going to release your package and what do you consider to be the minimum amount of time that the Australian people will need to fully evaluate its fairness or otherwise?

—At least Mr Tony Smith is not joining the Labor Party! We all, on occasions, suffer resignations in this business. I suspect that this resignation might have had more to do with a pending preselection than with any other particular matter. I am also not surprised that Mr Tony Smith, upon resigning, put out a statement in which he raised other issues that he uses to seek to justify his resignation.

answer.para: In relation to the GST, we can assure Mr Tony Smith and the Australian Democrats that this country is badly in need of tax reform. We can say that we have tackled a number of the major economic issues facing Australia. We have got expenditure under control. We were able to do it through taking hard but fair decisions that cut back public expenditure, which has contributed to getting interest rates down to the lowest level in 30 years— something from which all Australians can benefit.

talk.start.para: —No increases in tax.

—Yes, I will take the interjection. There have been no increases in income tax in three budgets, no increases in capital gains tax in three budgets and no new increases in wholesale sales tax in three budgets. When has all this occurred before? Okay. We took the hard decisions on expenditure. We have kept down taxes. We have taken sensible decisions on industrial relations which give all Australians the opportunity for more sustainable jobs and better opportunities for the future. But there is one major area of economic reform that is badly in need of attention, and that is the taxation system. Everyone knows that that is so. They know that the existing system is unfair. They know that it places an undue burden on production.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order on relevance. I have waited two minutes and the minister still—

interjection.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! I am entitled to hear Senator Lees's point of order.
—My question was not on the need for tax reform. My question was: what is the time line for the government's version of the tax reform they believe that we are supposed to be getting?
—Senator Hill, I just remind you of the question if you have matters to comment on.

—Yes, Madam President. I was getting to that. I was trying to put it in context and explain to Senator Lees why the matter is actually so important—the need for tax reform in this country. Obviously, we want to take the Australian people with us on that. That is why I am taking the opportunity to explain its importance. We are, in this era of globalisation, disadvantaged when we have extra taxes on production as opposed to our competitors. We need to get those taxes off production so we can provide even more jobs, and that will mean a switch in the incidence of some taxes.

answer.para: We will ensure that that comprehensive package—which is not an issue of indirect taxes; it is an issue of the appropriate level of income taxes and what level of incentive is necessary through the taxation system—which will deliver to Australia an updated, contemporary, economically efficient and fair taxation system, is put before the Australian people well before the election.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. We would just like to know when `well before the election' is. I ask the minister if he is aware of the level of general concern within the community? They do not trust you, Minister. They believe that we need—
—Order! Senators should listen to the question.

interjection.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my right!

—Minister, you have a number of backbenchers—the last one to be quoted is Paul Marek—who are also calling for an early release. I ask: are you keeping your members as much in the dark as you are keeping the rest of us? For the final time, what is your version of `sufficient time before an election'?

—It is our side of politics that is seeking to engender a debate on the issue of taxation. We do not want to keep anyone in the dark. I can tell Senator Lees that the election is due before March next year and the policy will be delivered well before March next year. It is our intention through the election to build upon the debate that we have commenced on taxation. Senator Lees might not appreciate the fact that most Australians actually do believe there is a need for taxation reform. Most Australians do believe the current system is unfair. Most Australians believe that, under the Labor Party in 13 years, they paid too much tax—and they are right. They want reform in this area. They will get it from this government, because this is a government that has demonstrated that it is prepared to take the hard economic decisions in order to provide better opportunities for all Australians.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer to the minister's attempt to keep his conflict of interest secret by not declaring his shareholdings to parliament for two years. Has the minister attempted the same trick in not declaring his significant coalfield property holdings through Kiskin Pty Ltd, including some 25 properties in the Bowen coal basin? Can the minister now explain to the Senate how many of Kiskin's property holdings have a direct or indirect relationship to the minister's portfolio responsibilities and, in particular, how many of the properties have coal deposits within them?
—I disclosed, as required, the interests that my family trust had in the various properties. One of the areas where they did have an interest—

answer.para: Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Conroy, you have been interjecting too frequently.

—and, I might say, a very minor interest, was in the Kiskin trust, which had real estate—property, that sort of thing. Madam President, I do not know the actual make-up of those particular properties, but I can take you back to 1995 or pre-1996.

answer.para: Senator Schacht interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order, Senator Schacht!

—I know we had a breathless reporter ringing around various shires asking, `What sorts of properties does Kiskin have? I have done searches and so on.' I think he quoted 25 or something; I read the newspaper article too. All I can say is that I have no idea what they are at this stage, but in those days the vast majority of those properties were in towns called Bluff and Blackwater. There was an article in the Sydney Morning Herald about it. Bluff is a tiny whistlestop village closer to the Jellinbah mine than is Blackwater. If the reporter had checked he would have found that the vast majority of those properties were houses for employees and contractors to live in.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. As the minister appears not to be able to answer the questions I have asked him, he might care to take them on notice. Minister, is this failure to disclose property holdings just another inadvertent breach of the duty to fully disclose relevant holdings, as was claimed to be the case with extensive shareholdings in companies such as Queensland Coal Mine Management Pty Ltd? Further, can the Senate expect another amendment to the Register of Pecuniary Interests, or can the minister now see the clear public perception of conflict of interests between ministerial duties and private share and property holdings?

—I have made a full disclosure. I provided the disclosure as required up until 1996. Senator Faulkner is well aware of the fact that I was unaware of the change that occurred. As soon as the changes occurred, I agree that he asked me a question in this place; I said I would make a full disclosure, so I did that. But in the meantime, of course, any interests that my wife or I had in the family trust have been disposed of and are now in the hands of the children that we have.
—Contrary to the Prime Minister's code.

—Madam President, it is quite obvious from the shouts coming from Senator Faulkner that, while he survives, the big-mouth owl will not be an endangered species.Senator Faulkner is aware that a full disclosure was made both pre the dates when I was aware of the changes and post the dates when we disposed of the assets. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. In the light of the release yesterday of the public consultation paper in relation to the WA regional forest agreement, I refer the minister to the story in today's West Australian , and in particular to the serious concerns raised about the validity or accuracy of the RFA following the destruction of the Hilliger block near Nannup. I ask: is it true that a senior officer in your department advised you on 22 January this year that the Hilliger block is `of very high conservation significance', and that there were concerns that the WA Minister for the Environment was not aware of that fact? What action did the minister take to alert the WA minister in relation to this issue to ensure that Hilliger was protected at least until the finalisation of the RFA? Does the minister not agree that the destruction of the Hilliger block highlights the real agenda of the WA Department of Conservation and Land Management, which is to actively support the continued logging of high conservation forests?

—I welcome the honourable senator reminding the Senate of the consultation paper that has just been issued in relation to the Western Australian regional forest agreement. After the debacle of Labor in relation to forest policy, the government, on the one hand, set about putting in place in this country a world-class set of reserves—world-class in terms of area and quality—and, on the other hand, sought to provide for the forest industry certainty of resource within a sustainable environment, and by `sustainable' I mean both economically sustainable and ecologically sustainable. If we can achieve those objectives, I think that most Australians would believe that we had done an excellent job in an area that has always been very controversial.

answer.para: I am pleased that we have been able to establish such a regional forest agreement in Tasmania, in East Gippsland and in the Central Highlands of Victoria, and I am pleased that we are making good progress towards the settlement of a regional forest agreement in Western Australia and another one in Eden in New South Wales. It will demonstrate that, by March of next year, we will have broken the back of this very difficult, but nevertheless very important, task in relation to both industry and conservation.

In relation to the Western Australian RFA, there will always be particular blocks that are in dispute. The one to which Senator Margetts refers actually is not included within the deferred area at all. There is a debate about its conservation values. The argument of the Western Australian authorities is that it has been degraded and that that part which is to be harvested is from the degraded part. These debates will continue and will be taken up within the next stage of this process, which is the public consultation and then the ultimate negotiation between governments.

We have six weeks for this period of public consultation. I hope Senator Margetts will put her point of view. I have been a little bit disappointed by the lack of contribution by conservation elements within Western Australia. I think they have missed an opportunity to constructively contribute to this process in Western Australia. But it is not too late. In the next six weeks, I look forward to the conservation movement's contribution to this debate.

In relation to the matter which was referred to in the newspaper, yes I read that an apparent document from my department was leaked, and that is unfortunate. But, unfortunately, these things happen. In relation to the contents of that document, certainly, as would reasonably be expected, I have had discussions with Minister Cheryl Edwardes about that particular block. As I said, the issue of the values of that block can be taken up in the final stages of the RFA process in Western Australia. Even though that particular block was not within the deferred area, while the deferred area gives a guide, it is nevertheless not the end of the picture as to which parts of the forest will ultimately be conserved under what I am confident will be a first-class conservation reserve that reflects the other quality conservation reserves that have come out of this process around Australia.

talk.start.para: —I have a supplementary question, Madam President. The area is certainly degraded now that it has been destroyed from its values. The minister mentions the conservation movement not being part of the process, and that, of course, has been mentioned to you by them, that they recognised the process for the farce that it was, as exemplified by what has happened in relation to Hilliger. Would the minister be prepared to table any advice or correspondence he received re Hilliger block; if so, when would that be received?

—If you have read it in the newspapers, you do not need to have it tabled. I am not going to dispute that there is a difference of view as to the conservation values of that particular block. I do not actually know of any forest block in Australia where there is not a debate about its qualities. That is reasonable and that is what you would expect. What I have been at pains to ensure through this process is that the debate is on the basis of sound scientific knowledge. I take this opportunity to thank the many dozens of scientists and other experts and volunteers who have constructively contributed to the process in Western Australia. It is on the basis of their contribution and on the basis of good science that I can be so confident that the outcome will be an outcome that is not only good for sustainable forest industry but particularly good for conservation as well.

—I direct my question to Senator Parer, the Minister representing the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs. Can the minister confirm that the tender specifications for the recent Cluster 3 IT outsourcing contract specified that public servants involved in tender evaluations could not be offered a position with a successful bidder? Is the minister aware that EDS Australia was recently selected by the Australian Customs Service to provide computing service over the next five years? Can the minister confirm that the chairman of the working group which chose EDS and a member of the tender process steering committee now have both been employed by EDS Australia? Has the minister satisfied himself that the Guide on Official Conduct of Commonwealth Public Servants in relation to the identification of a conflict of interest has been followed in this case?

—I am unaware of the detail raised by Senator Ray, therefore I am indebted to Senator Kemp for passing me a note on this matter. As I understand it, the facts are that the outsourcing of the Customs Service information technology function was conducted in accordance with the Department of Finance and Administration's guidelines on competitive tendering and contracting and that EDS, as Senator Ray said, was the successful tenderer. The two officers named in the article acted according to the Public Service and Merit Protection Commission's guidelines on outsourcing, which allow redundant staff to accept a voluntary retrenchment package and then to pursue employment elsewhere. The article acknowledges that the two staff did not break the rules. The Public Service and Merit Protection Commission's guidelines on official conduct have not been breached.

answer.para: There is no evidence, according to the minister, that the two former officers have made any unauthorised disclosures and no evidence that they unduly influenced the outcome of the tender negotiations to their benefit. The Crimes Act 1914 prohibits the unauthorised disclosure after leaving Commonwealth employment of information which an officer would have been prohibited from disclosing while they were still employed. This prohibition never ceases. As former employees, they are free to engage in other employment. The Commonwealth has a legislative and guidelines framework which safeguards official information and defines the parameters for tendering and outsourcing processes. The government demands high ethical standards of its employees, and as a measure of this the government included a code of conduct in the Public Service Bill. The code of conduct is explicit about the need to act honestly with integrity.

talk.start.para: —Just as well you are not a public servant.

—You would not know what that meant, would you, honesty and integrity? It also requires public servants to disclose conflict of interest and take reasonable steps to avoid this. These are critical to ensuring the highest standards of integrity among public servants.

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, you mentioned duties of public servants. Do those duties go to disclosing an apparent or perceived conflict of interest or just an actual conflict of interest, or a conflict of interest where one enriches themselves? Secondly, what is the appropriate role model for these public servants? Is it the Minister for Resources and Energy in his behaviour or is it the former Assistant Treasurer, Senator Short, Senator Gibson or Mr Prosser? What sort of example has the government set, and which of those examples would you recommend that public servants follow?

—Those on the other side have been going on and on about conflict of interest, and they came to the unhappy conclusion in the end that there was no conflict of interest and no perceived conflict of interest on my part or anybody else's in respect of this. They know that, so they started to change tack. We have seen it all before.

answer.para: Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —So we hear Senator Conroy over there talking about trusts. There are 400,000 people in the Australian community who have trusts which they operated quite legitimately under the previous government. These trusts are all much the same. There are 20,000 farmers who have trusts and most business people have them as well. Senator Ray, you are flogging a dead horse. You do not have the support of the general public out there who are recognising the fact over and over again that you are not interested in getting this country right. You brought it to its knees. We have rescued it, and all you can do is puddle around in mud.

—My question is to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. The minister will be aware of the editorial in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald entitled `No policy' referring to the opposition's `threadbare offering' on education that `lacks much merit'. `No policy' it said. I hope you note that, Senator Carr. The minister would also be aware of misleading statements made recently by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, in relation to school funding. Minister, will you correct the record and indicate how low and middle income earning Australians have benefited under this government's policies?

—I thank Senator Tierney for this very good question and acknowledge his longstanding interest in education. Of course, he is right—there was an editorial in today's Sydney Morning Herald which was entitled `No policy'. In fact, it referred to a `threadbare offering' in relation to the education policy mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition on the weekend. Let me say at the outset, not only the Leader of the Opposition but also the Australian Education Union has been intent on distorting this government's commitment to the future generation of this country and this government's education policy. Let us look at what the Leader of the Opposition said over the weekend. He said that if they got into government—fat chance of that—they would have a review of education in this country. It was only two years ago that they were in power—and they were in power for 13 years. In other words, all they can come up with is a review.

answer.para: But not only that, the Leader of the Opposition has gone back to the dark ages and said that they will do away with our current policy, which opened up choice for parents when we did away with the new schools policy. We gave the parents of Australia the choice between a strong government sector and a strong non-government sector. This government is committed to a strong government school sector and a strong non-government school sector so that parents can have a viable choice. But the Leader of the Opposition did away with that on the weekend: he said that if they get back into power they are going to do way with that choice and bring back the old new schools policy.
Look at what the Sydney Morning Herald went on to say in its editorial:
What these federations—
it means by that the Education Union—

want is not necessarily what education funding in Australia really requires. Mr Beazley has given his game away, in fact, with the promise of a "ground-up review of the entire Australian education system." This review creates a subsidised vehicle for the federations to drive their agendas forward.

That is what that editorial said and how right it is. Never mind the real issues of literacy, numeracy, drugs, civics education and vocational education in schools; let us just talk about doing away with the new school policy and having a ground-up review.

The other aspect of Senator Tierney's question relates to the distortion that is going on in relation to the funding and the commitment that this government has to schools and education in this country. Let us have a look at the facts. Compared with 1996, Labor's last year in office, this government has increased funding for schools by $580 million. When you look at that in relation to government schools the figure is $382 million. That is an increase since Labor was last in power of $382 million for this year. That is totally opposite to the distortion the Leader of the Opposition stated when he said that this government was likely to cut funds by $90 million over last year's figures. What we have in fact done is increase funding for government schools by $382 million in this year compared to the last year of Labor in power.

There are other aspects that this government is committed to. I mentioned numeracy and literacy. With the cooperation of the states and territories we have achieved national benchmarks in relation to literacy. We have also announced recent funding in relation to national Asian languages—$42 million odd there. We have announced funding of $187 million for a program of vocational education in schools until the year 2000—vocational education which will address the needs of those 70 per cent of students who do not go on to university. This is the commitment that this government has to the children of Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Can the minister confirm the government's promise to maintain the real value of housing programs for Aboriginal Australians? Has this promise been repeated by the minister at page 9 of his budget statement, `Addressing priorities in indigenous affairs'? Is the minister aware that the 1997-98 budget papers clearly show that there is a significant fall in funding for ATSIC's community housing and infrastructure program from $236.8 million in the 1997-98 revised estimates to $217.1 million in the 1998-99 estimates, both of which are well below the $238.5 million actually spent in 1995-96? Is the minister further aware that the ATSIC home ownership program is also shown to fall by over $5 million to $38.2 million in the coming year? (Time expired)
—Very good question. Try to answer that!

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —No problem! I suggest Senator Neal do a numeracy program that Senator Ellison was talking about and then she might be able to read the budget figures. We are in fact spending $700 million more in our first four years of government than the Labor Party did in their last four years. So there is actually more money going in. Senator Neal was here two years ago when I said that we were quarantining the funding for housing. And it was quarantined. ATSIC complained about it at the time but we have quarantined the reductions we had to make because we did have a $10.3 billion budget deficit that those on the other side seem to have forgotten about. We had to find savings within that budget because if we had projected on with the forward projections in that budget we would have been in a much more desperate position than we would be if the Labor Party was in power. So we do not resile from that. There were savings but we quarantined the amount of funding in relation to housing.

answer.para: The second part of Senator Neal's question was in relation to the home ownership program. The reality is that 50 per cent of Aboriginal people are totally dependent on welfare and 60 per cent are partially dependent on welfare. There are very few people who can actually access the program. So the amount of funding that went to the home ownership program has decreased to a degree because people do not want to take it up—they cannot afford it because of the Labor Party policies. They cannot afford it because for 13 years the Labor Party ran them into a desperate situation in relation to their own funding, making 50 per cent of them totally welfare dependent. There are very few people who can take up that program; in fact, only a little over 450 people actually take up that program.

If Senator Neal were to go to the trouble of looking at the booklet Rebutting the Myths, the home ownership program is all spelt out in that. I suggest that she reads this material so that she can see that we are improving, that we are devoting our attention to the basics of health, housing and education. That is what we are doing; that is what we have done in the first couple of years. We will continue to do so and we will not resile from that. We are putting more funds into housing, we are putting more funds into health and we are putting more funds into education. It is all in the budget papers. I am happy to provide Senator Neal with a graph which demonstrates quite clearly that the amount of funding is increasing and will increase over our first four years of government.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister also aware that the Aboriginal rental housing program, run by your colleague Senator Newman, has been pegged at the level of $91 million again, thereby continuing this government's trend of reducing the real value of this important program? If the Howard government cannot bring itself to say `sorry' for the trauma of the stolen generation, will you at least apologise for those blatant breaches of commitments to concentrate on services on the ground for Aboriginal Australians?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —We are concentrating on services on the ground. Talking about apologies, I think they should ask Gareth Evans to apologise to the Prime Minister for stating that he was only interested in bashing blackfellas. When are you going to get him to apologise? They are apologies all around the place. The Labor Party seems to be in the crying game these days. What wimps—all of them—dropping down and crying all over the place. I do not believe that is leadership.
—Senator Herron, I draw your attention to the substance of the supplementary question.

—Yes, Madam President. In reply to Senator Neal, we are devoting resources to things on the ground—the practical things. We sent the army in. Remember Senator Richardson wanting to turn a tap on and breaking down over the terrible things? I put the army in. We introduced the army-ATSIC program. We are about basics. We are about health, we are about housing and we are about education. We are putting $1.8 billion in. We are putting $700 million more in in our first four years of government than the Labor Party put in in their last four years. I suggest that Senator Neal should go back to the budget papers. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask: has the Australian government been asked to provide any form of assistance in President Habibie's review of government business dealings with former President Suharto and his family? Is the government aware of calls in Indonesia to locate the Suharto family wealth around the world, and will the Australian government work with the Indonesian administration in trying to locate the Suharto fortune in an effort to return to the Indonesian people some of the wealth amassed by that family and now located in Australia? Finally, does the government believe that the release of two political prisoners and the announcement of presidential elections within 12 months means that real democratic change is now probable in Indonesia?

—I am not aware of any such calls as suggested by Senator Bourne, but I will make inquiries in relation to that. Yes, we welcome the release of the two political prisoners. We see that as a positive sign and it is certainly a step in the right direction. We think that the best thing Australia can do at the moment is to be supportive of Indonesia, which is going through an economic crisis and a time of very dramatic political change.

answer.para: All Indonesians have suffered as a result of this economic crisis in terms of increased prices for basic essentials, lost jobs, lower income returns and the like. This has, as I have said before, contributed to significant social stress. The social stress has now played out its part in political change. As I said, I think that the most the constructive thing Australia can do is to be supportive of Indonesia during these difficult times; not to lecture or seek to impose outside solutions but to welcome positive change as it occurs. Hopefully we will witness a situation where the IMF support package might be further implemented as quickly as possible. That is the constructive and positive approach that this Australian government has taken to the difficulties in Indonesia, and that is where we stand on the issue at present.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I thank the minister for that answer. I note that he said that he does not believe that we can do an awful lot in Indonesia. But I also note that the Prime Minister was in the newspapers this morning saying that he believes, as I am sure most Australians do, that East Timor is a very important part of reform in Indonesia. Can the minister tell us what the government believes would be the most useful way to progress the situation in East Timor?

—Madam President, I did not think the honourable senator referred to East Timor in her question. In any event, in relation to the supplementary question, we have taken a position where we believe that a greater degree of autonomy is important in East Timor, as is a reduction in troop levels and the need to continue to provide aid—and I think Australia provides more aid to East Timor directly than any other country. These are efforts we can make to help overcome particularly the economic disadvantages of the people of East Timor. All of these are constructive and positive moves that Australia can play and is playing. I must correct the honourable senator: if she interpreted what I said to be that we could not do an awful lot, that is not exactly what I said. I think we are playing a very worthwhile and constructive role and will continue to do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Is the minister aware of recent comments by small business operators that employment services they used to receive free from the CES will now cost them up wards of $18,000 a year? Is the minister further aware that employers have said they are likely to turn to recruiting from backpackers hostels, thereby replacing young Australians with overseas tourists, directly as a result of this new tax on employment? How can the Howard government explain to Australian small businesses, such as the operators of the Glendambo truck-stop and the Marla Travellers Rest complex, that this new employment tax will better serve their recruitment needs?

—Senator Mackay, there is a teleservice vacancy centre, and you can phone that on 131715. I repeat that: 131715. There is no cost associated with that, and job seekers have access to that touch screen. As I said to you yesterday, Senator Mackay, there are some 310 organisations involved. Some of those may charge fees; some may not. It is a question of choice in relation to job seekers. But the service I just mentioned to you on 131715 is a free service and for eligible workers—job seekers, as I mentioned—there is of course no fee attached.

answer.para: On your question in relation to backpackers, I do not believe that will impinge upon the chances of Australian job seekers. I believe that, with the new program we have, there are only more opportunities than there were previously for job seekers in this country to find work.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, I remind you that the Employment National fee schedule is $300 to $2,000. If the government continues to parade the fallacy that these new commercial and expensive labour market services will produce better results for Australian employers, why aren't employers swallowing the government's line? Why are they turning instead to advertising at backpacker hostels? Doesn't this just back up the complaints being made about the new labour market arrangements by the government's own backbenchers or will the government be ignoring the serious complaints of the members for the Northern Territory, Richmond and Capricornia?

—I repeat myself: with the increase in the number of organisations—some 310 organisations—people in regional Australia now have more organisations available to help them. We have increased vastly the number of CES sites. We have some 1,400 sites in place, which is vastly better for job seekers than the previous number of CES sites, which was very much less. What we have now is a question of choice. Employment National will have to face its competitors in the market place. It is a question of choice for job seekers. Employers and small businesses can go to those people who do not charge—it is up to them.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, the tax burden on low-and middle-income earners massively increased during 13 years of a Labor government. Is the minister aware of alternative tax proposals, and how do these compare with the Howard government's assistance for families and small businesses?
—I am pleased that we have been able to squeeze this question in because it is a very important issue.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! It is necessary for me to hear the answer. Those listening on television and radio are also entitled to hear.

—Madam President, it is a very important issue. We heard Mr Beazley at the weekend promise lower taxes. This is the Labor Party promising lower taxes! The problem is that the Labor Party has form on the subject of taxation. They cannot be believed on taxation because they are the high-tax alternative of Australian politics. Think of the 1993 budget: that was the L-A-W tax promise—not a promise but law. The Australian people can rely on it, said the Labor Prime Minister. What happened after the election? It disappeared. Instead the Australian people got increases in petrol tax; increases in tobacco excise; increases in fringe benefits tax; wholesale sales taxes went up.

answer.para: The people can look to the 1995 budget only two years later. What happened there? Sales tax on cars went from 15 per cent to 22 per cent; the Medicare levy was increased; in creased pharmaceutical charges; company taxes increased from 33 to 36 per cent; the provisional uplift factor increased of course under Labor. This is what Labor is all about. In 1995-96 alone, there was a 9.3 per cent real increase in the tax take. That is because Labor is the high-tax alternative of Australian politics—and we know just below the surface it is still there.

What did former senator Gareth Evans, now the shadow Treasurer, say in October 1996? He said Australia is `so undertaxed'. The shadow Treasurer is saying Labor is undertaxing when Mr Beazley, the leader, is saying Labor will give you taxation reductions. Who could believe him? Mr Evans said Australia is so undertaxed by all relevant international standards that there is a case for having some overall revenue increases. Mr Evans is saying revenue increases, and he talked about possible death duties, property taxes, income tax surcharges—this is what Mr Evans is talking about—and increased payroll taxes.

Even yesterday what did Mr Evans say? He said Labor could not rule out new taxes. Mr Beazley last weekend was saying to the Australian people, `We will reduce taxes.' Mr Evans, the shadow Treasurer, said that we cannot rule out new taxes. What he said was:
It's not so much a matter of new taxes and charges, perhaps a little bit of rearrangement or broadening of existing tax scales elsewhere.

So who can believe the Labor leader when at the same time his shadow Treasurer is going out and not ruling out tax increases? When you combine their form, their form is to increase taxes. With the statements from Mr Evans, their shadow Treasurer, the Australian people can be confident that all they would get from Labor is increased taxes, new taxes, expanded taxes and broadened taxes. That is what the Labor Party is all about—and what a contrast it is with the current government, which has got through three budgets without any new taxes.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—Yesterday in question time Senator Jacinta Collins asked me some questions without notice about referrals of unemployed people by Centrelink to new employment agencies, and I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Yesterday in the Senate, Senator Jacinta Collins asked me questions without notice about referrals of unemployed people by Centrelink to new employment agencies
I am now in a position to respond I am advised that:

. by 25 May, Centrelink had assessed over 277,000 jobseekers and referred over 77,800 jobseekers to Intensive Assistance (the most personalised and intensive service for disadvantaged jobseekers) Over 4,300 jobseekers have been referred to Job Search Training (providing training in job search techniques) by Centrelink and thousands of new jobs have been lodged on the National Vacancy Data Base by Job Network Members;

. referrals from Centrelink to Intensive Assistance have reached 82% of the 95,000 target of referrals to Job Network Members for Intensive Assistance to be achieved by the end of May and 87% of the Job Search Training referral target;
. the targets will be achieved in most regions Centrelink has put in place strategies to meet the referral targets. Any shortfall that may arise will be addressed in June;

. Job Network members are not guaranteed a set number of referrals It is up to jobseekers to choose the organisation which best suits their needs As planned and subject to jobseeker choice, Job Network Members can expect to have close to full capacity soon after the start of the new financial year;

. compared with how long it took to get a much smaller change fully operational with Case Management arrangements under the previous Government—the introduction of Job Network has been an outstanding success.
In respect of aspects of the question relating to the financial circumstances of the new job agencies, I have been advised by Dr Kemp's office that

. Job Network members have always been fully aware that they will be paid on the basis of results—that is, they will be paid the bulk of their fees when a jobseeker has been placed in a job for 13 weeks and then 26 weeks—so the bulk of fees would not be received until some time after the market commenced

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Yesterday Senator Forshaw asked me a question in relation to the Minister for Health and the AMA. I have been provided with an answer to that question, and I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SENATOR FORSHAW : My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is the Minister aware that the Howard Government has now completely alienated every group involved in health care in Australia, including patients and potential patients; clients of private health funds; health fund operators; nursing home operators; doctors, nurses and other staff; and State and Territory Governments which are attempting to keep the public health system afloat? Can the Minister confirm that the doctors' professional association, the AMA, is now refusing to speak to the Minister, Dr Wooldridge, and will only negotiate directly with the Prime Minister because of the poisonous relationship Dr Wooldridge has established with them? Isn't it time that the Government admitted that the crisis in public hospitals, in private health insurance and in aged care is beyond the capacity of Minister Wooldridge, as the AMA clearly already believes?

SENATOR FORSHAW : Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. It is interesting to note that apparently the Minister does not even read newspapers, let alone press releases or indeed the specific comments of the representatives of the AMA. Minister, along with the AMA and the various other organisations involved in health care that I have referred to in my question, we now even have Ministers, colleagues of Dr Wooldridge, expressing their concern. Minister, when will the Howard Government respond to Minister Newman's call to "do more on health"? Minister, does not Senator Newman's comment, together with those from the Treasurer, Mr Costello, and from all the State Coalition Health Ministers clearly indicate that even Coalition colleagues are very unhappy with Minister Wooldridge's performance in the health portfolio?

The report regarding the AMA is without foundation Over the past two years, the AMA has met from time to time with staff of the Prime Minister Over the same period, the AMA has met far more frequently with the Minister for Health and Family Services, his office and his Department The AMA is represented on many committees and working parties in the Health portfolio In terms of recent comment, when commenting on the 1998-99 Budget, the President of the AMA said that few Health Ministers could claim to have taken initiatives which would save lives, but that Dr Wooldridge, through his initiatives to provide flu vaccine free of charge for older Australians, could confidently make this claim I would again remind honourable Senators, especially Senator Forshaw, that you obviously can't believe everything you read in the papers.

talk.start.para: —Pursuant to standing order 74(5), I ask Senator Herron, the minister representing the Minister for Health, why I have not been provided with an answer to question on notice No. 864, which is now the grand total of 239 days overdue. I also ask why I have not received an answer to question No. 1168, which is also overdue.

speech.para: I do stress that, in relation to the first question, it is 239 days overdue and, even by the measure of this government, that does seem an extraordinarily long period of time.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I contacted the minister's office and I am advised by the office of the Minister for Health and Family Services that answers to these questions will be provided to the Senate as soon as possible after Dr Wooldridge returns from overseas next week.
—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the explanation.
In the circumstances of a debate about to take place on taking note of questions, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Senator Ellison), to questions without notice asked by Senators Mackay and West and today, relating to the provision of employment services.

Let us have a look at what this government has done with regard to the new employment services market. As we have travelled around Australia on the regional unemployment inquiry, my colleagues Senator George Campbell, Senator Crowley and Senator Carr and I have had it amply demonstrated to us just what a mess this new system is. There is absolutely no doubt.

It is riddled with inconsistencies and with complete imponderables as to how the tender process was awarded and what type of decision making process was in fact instituted. I think it is quite bizarre. We have talked to groups that missed out to find out why they missed out, but they themselves are saying, `We have no idea in terms of feedback.'

Let us look at the reality. Operator after operator and provider after provider have been impeccable in terms of service delivery. In fact, out of ESRA's top ten service delivery agencies for case management last year, only four got a guernsey in the new employment services market. ESRA is now defunct. but it was the agency responsible for determining which organisations are the most productive and efficient in terms of providing services. Out of that whole top ten, only four got a guernsey in terms of any FLEX whatsoever.

Despite the minister's obfuscation, there is no doubt that there have been massive cuts in service provision, massive cuts in the number of sites available to unemployed people and massive cuts in expenditure. This is a matter of some interest.

Through estimates and also through questions on notice we have been trying to obtain details of the commitment that the minister gave at his media conference when he announced the new employment services market. He said he would provide details of how much money was available, how much money the whole system was costing, how much money was going to FLEX 1, FLEX 2, FLEX 3 and entry level training, and so on. He gave that commitment to the entire press gallery, but we have not been able to get the information. I will bet that they have not been able to get it either.

As we talk to groups around Australia, they are extremely confused and bewildered. In many instances they are hurt as to why they got nothing. They were told in feedback interviews that the whole system was actually based on profit, despite the tender documents themselves saying that a demonstrable history of service provision would be taken into account and had equal weighting with the issue of profit in terms of criterion. They have just been told they are not profitable.

We have no way of no knowing this, because the government hides behind commercial-in-confidence and we cannot get hold of any of the information. They say, `Trust us. We are from the government.' Excuse me; we don't.

The government's mantra is, `Competition is good. If you put it out to competition, the free market will produce better outcomes.' I will quote the New Zealand Minister of Employment whom we saw last week when we were in New Zealand. The New Zealand coalition government is not noted for its left of centre politics by any stretch of the imagination. He said:
I am opposed to what you are doing in Australia. I am opposed to the high level of competition in the employment area. It doesn't work.

This is coming from New Zealand; land of laissez faire, land of the free market, where anything is regarded as a market distortion, but the Minister of Employment there is saying, `We are not going to do what this government has done in Australia, because I do not believe it works.'

I turn now to the whole issue of Employment National. The reality is that Employment National is not a private company, despite what Peter Storey likes to tell you. It is not a private company. Employment National has received $130 million over two years of taxpayers' money to provide a service. It is outrageous that Employment National is trying to say, `We are not accountable.' They are accountable. They are accountable to the people of Australia through the provision of that money, and they are also accountable with regard to estimates.

In that regard, we now have the situation where Employment National is charging small business—the very constituency that this government attempts to purport to represent—between $300 and $2,000 for services that the CES previously provided for free. I think that is absolutely outrageous. I believe that the bottom line is that this is a de facto jobs tax. It is something that small businesses never anticipated would happen, and now they are starting to scream.

talk.start.para: —I found it interesting listening to Senator Mackay's remarks on this motion to take note of answers. Of course, she was not around for very much of the former Labor government, which had such a disgraceful record on unemployment. When the opposition now starts to criticise the current government for its policies on unemployment, its members should think back to their own record and how hopeless that was.

speech.para: Senator Mackay, you mentioned the CES, but what you did not mention was the success rate of the CES of placing people in jobs—or, should I say, Senator Mackay, the lack of success rate. Isn't that the bottom line of employment programs? Surely the bottom line is not how much money is spent on those programs; the bottom line is how many people at the end get jobs. Under the program that you had, under the CES that you propped up year after year at great expense, was very little job outcome.

When you brought in Working Nation, you had a similar sort of result. You spent hundreds of millions on it—hundreds of millions. Yet what was the job outcome? Two-thirds of those individuals ended up back on the dole queues. What a brilliant outcome that was!

Obviously the approach had to be different, and this government is taking a very different approach. The Senate Committee on Employment, Education and Training decided that it would go around Australia and have a look at these things, thinking that around Australia, particularly in regional Australia, there would be terrific outrage about this new scheme when compared with the old scheme. A reasonable measure of what the outrage is, I suppose, would be the number of people putting in submissions to these inquiries.

One spot we plan to go to is Launceston and, as of last week, four submissions had been received; in Burnie, zero submissions. Then the plane will go to Ballarat, from which two submissions have been received. But the classic is Nowra—one submission from Nowra.

talk.start.para: —How many submissions?
—One in Nowra.Then the committee will go to the Hunter Valley and the central coast; two submissions have been received from that area.
—How much does the committee cost?

—On our estimates, it costs somewhere up around $100,000 for all of this, seeing very few people at all. Then we go out to western Sydney; certainly complaints would be expected to be found out there. There have been three submissions: one from Blacktown council, one from Liverpool council and one from Fairfield council. But where is the hearing held? The hearing is held in Parramatta. Why Parramatta? These people do not know their geography. It is being held in Parramatta—
—Is it a marginal seat?
—Yes, you have got it. Thank you very much for reminding me of that.
—Order! Senator Tierney, would you like to address the chair, please?
—Through you, Madam Chair. It is just absolutely amazing—
—No, to me.

—that, out of the 17 spots this committee is visiting, 15 happen to be marginal seats held by the Liberal Party. It is backfiring. Come into New South Wales and it will really backfire, because who dismantled labour market programs in New South Wales? The Carr government. You come to New South Wales and we will tell you all about that in the hearing. That government just gave up, withdrew, got out of employment programs.

speech.para: What this government is doing is actually putting in place programs that will work. Under the CES, it did not work. But, under this new approach with Jobs Network and the other providers, we are providing over 300 centres where people can go to get assistance with employment. The people who are putting up these programs, to get their full money in the end, will have to provide real jobs at the end—not like your previous programs.

Working Nation was training for jobs that did not exist. If you did not get a job, you went on another training program. How disheartening to these people. We have set up a totally different approach—an approach which will mean that people at the end are much more likely to get jobs. That is what I thought job market programs were all about.

talk.start.para: —What a ridiculous little contribution that was. Senator, what we are debating here is the insufficiency of Senator Ellison's answer to questions from this side. The first thing Senator Ellison said was, `I'm not aware.' That would describe not only the minister but also the government. They are not aware.

speech.para: Senator Ellison is not aware that you have to go up one floor to get to the Bathurst office—and that is an impossibility for people with disability. He is not aware of the fact that so many people in the community who applied to get some of these contracts have been overlooked, while people with no office, no money, no staff—no anything—have been paid $1 million in one case, and $15 million in the case of Hospitality Horizons, and organisation which is supposed to be out of Sydney helping people, for one part, in South Australia.

The other interesting thing is that Hospitality Horizons does not necessarily provide anything itself. It will be subcontracting all of those 310 jobs, or whatever number it is. Senator Tierney, I note, is leaving the cham ber because he is not prepared to stay and take the facts.

talk.start.para: —He does the same thing at the inquiries—he takes off and doesn't listen anyway.

—That is a very good point—in fact, for those times he attends at all. Hospitality Horizons is subcontracting to other organisations, and very often indeed to organisations in the community that previously applied and were rejected by this government. Now Hospitality Horizons, for one example, is getting those people back onto the books—but, when it does do that, it takes a commission. So, every time that organisation subcontracts, taxpayers' hard earned dollars are now going for a commission. And can we establish the value of that commission? No.

speech.para: Why should taxpayers be subsidising an organisation to take a cut or a kickback every time it subcontracts to those organisations already on the ground who were denied the continuance of that work by this government? Every time they are brought back into the fold, Hospitality Horizons, one for one, is taking a cut.

Senator Hill, you should be interested—through you, Madam Deputy President—because a lot of that organisation's work out of Sydney is to go to South Australia. When we were in South Australia—in Whyalla, Port Augusta, Port Pirie, north and south of Adelaide—not one of those positions had been filled. There was nobody providing job assistance. There was nobody there to provide any of this. According to the department, the money has been paid, but nobody is providing any service at all.

When we were in Craigieburn one of the people there said, `I would like to tell you what has happened to us. I rang this number to find out where my nearest unemployment agent office was.' Somebody on the phone asked, `How can I help you?' This woman said, `I am in Craigieburn and I want to know where my nearest Employment National office is or any office that can assist me.' The lady said, `Where is Craigieburn?' `Oh,' said the woman ringing up. `Where are you?' She said, `I am in Perth. I do not know anything about Craigieburn.'

The big message from this inquiry is that what the community wants—if the minister or any of those coalition members over them went—is local knowledge. They want people who know about the jobs in their area, who want to know about unemployment in their area, who want to know about the skills and talents of the people in that area. They do not want people miles away across the nation down a telephone answering questions about Melbourne from Perth when the people in Perth properly have no expert knowledge at all.

The system, as far as we have been able to discover it and explore it to this point, is a total, unmitigated fiasco. We have had the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) telling us about security, safety and stability. According to the lot over there, I think those three `s's should be replaced with others; namely, smugness and self-satisfaction. You are sitting there complacently. We just heard Senator Tierney saying that things will be much better. They are not; they are a shambles. We are unable to discover how many taxpayers' dollars are going where under this veil of commercial in confidence. You should take no satisfaction from this. It is a disaster. It is a disaster that is already happening.

People are very disinterested and disappointed with what you have put in place. As Senator Ellison said, `If the office in Bathurst cannot help you, go to another one.' As one of my colleagues has said, it is a long way in a wheelchair to another employment agency. What kind of government, what kind of compassion, security or stability will that give people when they are told by the minister, `I am not aware, I do not know.' It is a disaster out there. It is not waiting to happen; it is happening right now. Coalition colleagues should stand utterly condemned, and you will be at the next election.

talk.start.para: —Yet again we have heard another barrage of scaremongering on the part of Labor senators opposite. What needs to be understood is that this government has introduced a new system of employment services because of the failure of Labor's system. The system that Labor had in place for all their years in office proved to be a dismal failure. Their system did not succeed through the old CES in placing unemployed people in real, long-term jobs in any significant numbers. As I said, it is because of that failure that the government has taken the initiative and set up a new system which will provide a much better service. The previous arrangement simply did not work effectively in getting people into jobs.

speech.para: Too often under Labor, job seekers were merely churned through costly, ineffective and complex so-called training programs with little regard for the individual needs of the particular unemployed person concerned or with no job involved at the end of it. The focus was on process and program placements rather than the needs of the individual and the job opportunities that were available. What we had under Labor was training for training's sake rather than effective placement in a job. Job seekers were expected to fit the program rather than, as should have been the case and as will be the case under the new employment services programs initiated by these changes, the programs fitting the job seeker.

Another thing that needs to be understood is that the Commonwealth Employment Service under the old system had only a very limited share of the available vacancies—about 20 per cent. Most of the jobs that were available in the community in small, medium and large business were filled through advertising, word of mouth or other means rather than by placement by the Commonwealth Employment Service.
