We needed to change that and get a results driven system into place that would serve the needs of the unemployed. That is exactly what we have done. We have introduced a results driven system. Jobs network members will be paid to place unemployed people in jobs and not simply to continue managing the unemployed.

Another thing that became evident under Labor was that those involved had a long-term interest in dependency on government, in keeping people dependent on government, instead of making them independent of government by finding them appropriate employment and by being required to place them in jobs rather than managing their unemployment. That is the essence of the changes that have been made under the new scheme which came into effect at the beginning of this month—the replacement of the Commonwealth Employment Service by the new jobs network. This is a national network of more than 300 private, community and government organisations specialising in finding jobs for unemployed people, and especially dealing with the long-term unemployed and finding the right jobs for them.

In making these changes, the government is making employment services more effective and is focusing on the outcomes, on the results, getting unemployed people into jobs and providing help that genuinely makes a difference to them. Jobs network members will be paid to place unemployed people in jobs. Because of the broad spread—and I said that some 300 or so organisations were involved in this—there will be three to four times more sites than were available under the CES as a source of assistance for unemployed people. Similarly, employers will have a far greater choice of organisations to find the right person for their job vacancies.

As far as Commonwealth services relating to employment assistance and other Commonwealth assistance is concerned, Centrelink has now been well established and is operating effectively in providing an easier, better and more efficient way for people to obtain those Commonwealth services. That is now the base where unemployed people register for work and receive their unemployment benefit and government assistance. Centrelink provides the initial gateway entry for benefits for those on unemployment benefits to obtain that assistance, and it is also the gateway to the jobs network. It will be Centrelink that provides the link, very appropriately, between unemployed people and the jobs network members in their area. A very effective system has been established by the government to overcome the dismal failures of the previous Labor government system which did not succeed. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is worth noting that this new scheme, or Jobs Network, only came into effect on 1 May. It has been, in fact, in operation for 25 days and already there is sufficient anecdotal evidence to suggest that it will turn out to be an absolute national disgrace; an absolute national disgrace in terms of what it is projected to do compared with what it will do. My colleagues Senator Crowley and Senator Mackay gave some examples—anecdotal evidence—of what is occurring in practice out in the field with Jobs Network. I have also come across a few examples.

speech.para: When we were on the regional unemployment inquiry in Broken Hill, we were told by people in Broken Hill that the company that had won the contract—the people who were providing the employment services in Broken Hill—was located in Bendigo—a considerable distance, I would suggest, away from Broken Hill. In fact, I dare say that they had never visited Broken Hill in the whole period of their existence.

Another example was given to me the other day by Senator Sherry who was approached by one of his constituents who had rung up the service which was providing employment services to Burnie. After spending a considerable period of time waiting in the queue, she spoke to the person at the other end of the line. After going through the procedures and processes they said, `Where do you live?' She said, `I am located in Burnie.' They said, `Isn't that a suburb of Hobart?' Where was the person located that was providing this service to Burnie? In Sydney! There is a range of examples already starting to emerge to suggest that this will turn into a national disgrace.

Senator Chapman said that employers were happy about the new service being provided by Employment National. An article appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 11 May that would tend to suggest otherwise. It referred to the experiences of a Mr Richard Bullock, who runs a restaurant in Lane Cove in Sydney. He said that over the years—free of charge—the CES would provide a list of unemployed candidates from which he could pick workers for his Lane Cove restaurant. The article states:

So when Mr Bullock called Chatswood CES recently looking for a kitchenhand, he was surprised to find that not only did the CES no longer exist—but its replacement, Employment National, wanted to charge $250 to send him the resumes of three suitable candidates.
And if he wanted a `fully-screened' prospective employee, he would have to pay $800.
It was a case of welcome to the user-pays, deregulated employment market, Mr Bullock said.
He went on to say:
"They have taken away a source of employees for employers which worked extremely well. Some of my best employees have been long-term unemployed people the CES found."
The changes have angered small businessmen such as Mr Bullock, who said that a free service that encouraged employers to take on workers—especially the long-term unemployed—had disappeared.
A spokesman for Employment National said the services that were provided through the CES were no longer available but that there was no fee for an employer simply to lodge notice of a vacancy.
Well done! It continues:
The spokesman said that if employers wanted unscreened workers for no charge, other employment agencies offered this service.

We do not know where those other unemployment agencies are. They do not appear to exist because they all seem to be very focused on earning a buck. Those comments of Mr Bullock are very important in understanding the dimension of this problem; the dimension that you people on the other side of this chamber have created in terms of the capacity of unemployed people to get into jobs and into jobs quickly—because Mr Bullock, as far we know, is not a supporter of the Labor Party but a very committed supporter of the Liberal Party. But he has got enough gumption and commonsense, in running a business, to understand. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I also rise to speak on the answers given by Senator Ellison. We have heard from senators opposite today words such as `outrageous', from Senator Mackay; a `lack of compassion' and `a disaster', from Senator Crowley; and from Senator George Campbell we heard anecdotal evidence of a `disgrace.' What we actually have here is evidence that is best summed up by the member for Sydney and a former Minister for Education, Peter Baldwin, when he said Labor's policies failed young people, and:

speech.para: Accommodating the needs of those not intending to proceed directly to university in the final years of schooling is something that we did not do enough of in government.

There is nothing anecdotal about the evidence of the problem that we inherited when we came into government in 1996. What we found was no anecdotal evidence of a disgrace, it was an actual disgrace; it was outrageous; and, if Senator Crowley was here, it certainly lacked compassion and you could describe it as a total disaster. We had hundreds of thousands of our young people with no jobs, no job prospects, churned through make-work job schemes. Working Nation could not have been worse named if you had sat down and thought about the name for a week.

We gave those young people a clear message: they did not need to get out of bed, they did not need to get off the couch, they did not need to leave the video shop or the television screen. They had no prospects at all. They had no chance of getting work and they knew it. The previous government did nothing to address the concerns of those young people. Many of them, I am sad to say, were in my own state of South Australia, and the ongoing evidence of the disaster created by some of those policies was brought before the committee that I also have the privilege to serve on, which Senator Tierney referred to earlier in this place.

What we have tried to do, in giving these young people a chance to get some work, is to create job opportunities in a different form. Let us just have a look at what we have offered: of the 310 Job Network organisations, 148 are private, 143 are community and 19 are government—including of course the federal government owned Employment National. The benefits for job seekers and employers under the Job Network include access to more than 1,400 Job Network sites across this country—more than four times the 296 CES sites that were previously available. Thousands of extra job vacancies will be on the touch screens at the Centrelink offices, when the CES in fact had only 20 per cent of all job vacancies. What we are trying to do in providing these opportunities is to give those young people who choose not to go on to university a chance to find a real job—a chance to be educated and then have some job opportunities.

When I looked at the alternative opportunity that the Labor Party in government would offer as part of their education policy, I was very interested to note a description offered by the Sydney Morning Herald, in its editorial of just a day or so ago, that it was `a threadbare offering that lacks much merit.' So what was this other opportunity? It was yet another round table, a policy review. As I calculate it now, that makes four: an education round table, a native title round table, a tax round table and a waterfront round table. This is going to be some sort of a table; it is going to be a very big table; there are going to be lots of little round knees under it. People will be sitting on little round chairs, talking empty words and trying to address the disgraceful problems that were left to this government when we took office: the problem of the Native Title Act, the problem of an antiquated tax system, the disgraceful problem on the waterfront, and now the difficulties that we are having in trying to find jobs for those thousands of young people who were without work at the time when we came to office. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Mackay) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 and the Corporations Law, in order to help protect the entitlements of employees.
Motion (by Senator Mackay) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

Madam President, the Employment Security Bill 1998 amends the Workplace Relations Act 1996 and the Corporations Law. The Labor Party is moving these amendments in order to help protect the entitlements of employees.
The aim of this bill is to put an end to the Patrick-style scams where companies seek to avoid their legal obligations to their employees.
Madam President, job security, is a vital and fundamental issue for all Australians.
Job security is fundamental to all aspects of family life and it is a matter of concern to the entire community.
Many Australian workers are anxious about the security of their jobs and their future, and they are right to be anxious because they have a government which has set out to destroy job security.
This objective of the government is not new. Senator Vanstone let the cat out of the bag back in September 1997 when she talked about the need for "lessened job security".

The federal government has pursued this objective with such vigour and such a degree of ideological zeal that we have seen the government actively participate and connive with Patricks in the sacking of 1400 workers. The Minister for Workplace Relations and the Prime Minister boastfully confirmed their support for what can only be described as a corporate `scam' by Patrick to sack its workforce.
This government schemed with Patricks to break its own workplace relations act, in actions that 10 out of 11 judges found to be arguably illegal.
By this government's actions it has created an unprecedented sense of job insecurity amongst Australians and has allowed a dubious employer to evade the law and, in fact, to become a law unto itself.
The Labor Party will not be a party to this laissez-faire, "leave it to the market" approach to industrial relations.
The Labor Party will not abrogate its responsibility to Australian families and we will not stand by and watch this government threaten workers' job security.
The government's spin doctors have tried to ameliorate the community outrage by saying that the Patrick's circumstances are unique. Wrong! Wrong! Wrong!
It can happen again and with this compliant and supportive government, it is likely to do so.
This bill, Madam President, is to ensure that workers are protected from these sorts of scams and that workers are given a measure of job security.
The bill explicitly addresses the circumstances of the corporate scam Patrick engaged in when it sacked its workforce.

For the benefit of the Coalition, I will now highlight the exact nature of Patrick's scam, as it appears that they have up to now been either unable or unwilling to grasp the pervasive implications of these actions.

The scam originated in the Minister's Department. Mr Derren Gillespie, in a minute to the Minister, told Mr Reith that the entire workforce had to be dismissed. The next step was Mr Corrigan's. He orchestrated a corporate structure which accommodated this.
The Patrick companies that employed the labour within the Patrick group were stripped of their assets. Most of these assets went upstream to other companies in the Patrick Group.

The only significant asset left with the Patrick employing companies was a contract to supply labour to the rest of the Patrick group. This had a provision, which the administrators described in their report as onerous, providing that if there was any interruption in the supply of labour by, for example, industrial action, the Patrick group could terminate the labour hire contract and obtain their labour from other sources.
These changes in the Patrick corporate structure were made without the knowledge of the workforce.

The workers did not know that they were actually employed by companies that were little more than $2 companies. The workers did not know that the company's contract to supply labour to the Patrick group could be terminated on such easy grounds.
I will remind senators of the circumstances when Patrick `terminated' their entire workforce of 1,400 workers. I quote from the Herald Sun (9/4/98):
"Patrick Stevedoring Company's clandestine sacking of 1400 waterside workers is a tragedy . . .
It is a sad when confrontation reaches the point where one side regards dismissal enforced by savage dogs and anonymous security guards as the only way forward . . .
This brings a new dimension to industrial relations in this country."
The editorial went on to say:

". . . the reaction of Mr Reith and the Prime Minister, John Howard, makes it clear that the government was involved in the strategy which led to the sackings. So much so, that it immediately committed itself to putting up $250 million so Patrick can make redundancy payments to its sacked workers."
The image of masked security guards and savage dogs is an image foreign to Australians and it is an image that will not be easily forgotten by the Australian community, I can assure you.

Patrick relied on this new structure to sack its workforce. The Patrick group determined that grounds had been made out to terminate the labour hire contracts with the Patrick employing companies, and those contracts were terminated. The Patrick group then determined that they were free to hire labour from other sources—which they did, hiring labour from the National Farmers' Federation Company, P&C Stevedores.
At the same time the Patrick employing companies were placed in receivership, having lost their only significant asset—the contract to supply labour to the Patrick group.
The employees of the Patrick labour hire companies were, as a result, left without their two most important rights:

1. Any claims for accrued entitlements—like annual leave and sick pay, redundancy pay, and long service leave—could only be made against their direct employer, the $2 Patrick labour hire companies, now in receivership.
2. Their right to be protected against unlawful termination was rendered meaningless.

The workers could only be reinstated to their direct employer—the Patrick employing companies—but those companies were in receivership, and, in any event, the Patrick Group would be under no obligation to take labour from those companies.

A reinstatement order is therefore of no practical effect, even though the workers were sacked illegally, because they were union members. This is a clear breach of the workplace relations provisions concerning freedom of association.
The Prime Minister confessed on `A Current Affair' that the reason why the entire Patrick workforce was dismissed, was because "they're all part of the one union". He went on to say:
"One of the consequences of having a bargaining monopoly, ruthlessly used in the hands of the union that won't listen to reason, is that some innocent people get affected."
This is clearly unlawful and I will remind the senators opposite of what the Workplace Relations Act says in this regard. Subsection 170CK(2), states, in part:
". . . . An employer must not terminate an employee's employment for any one or more of the following reasons, . . . ."
And one of the reasons stated is:
"(b) trade union membership or participation in trade union activities outside working hours or, with the employer's consent, during working hours;"
As I said before, the government has tried to say that the circumstances of the Patrick corporate scam were unique. That is just plain wrong.
Any corporate group could organise their structure so that employees are employed by internal labour hire company, with a tenuous agreement to supply labour to the rest of the group.

Indeed, many corporate groups, for quite legitimate reasons, already have separate companies within the group that employ the labour, just as separate companies own the assets, own the land, hold the debt, or hold the tax losses. A corporate group could easily alter this structure so that they could do what Patrick did.
Any employee who is employed in this sort of structure is effectively without any job security.

They still have a legal entitlement to redundancy pay, long service leave, accrued holiday and sick pay, but that is only enforceable against a company which is only a $2 company. There will be no assets to provide these entitlements on termination. So, in actuality they stand to lose all their entitlements.
Employees have a legal right not to be sacked illegally, but any reinstatement order is only enforceable against the direct employer, which may not have work to provide to the employees.
This is why our bill is so important.
The Patrick scam could happen to anyone. Any employee could be left without an effective means of getting reinstated to their job, or getting their accrued legal entitlements.
This bill ensures that this cannot happen again. It gives employees a measure of job security.
It does so by making amendments to both the Workplace Relations Act and the Corporations Law.
I will now briefly describe our intention. The two amendments to the Workplace Relations Act are as follows:

. First, section 170JI of the bill, allows the Court or Commission, when it finds that an employee has been unlawfully or unfairly dismissed and should be reinstated, to make the reinstatement order against companies that are related to the direct employer. At present reinstatement can only be ordered against the direct employer itself.
. The Court or Commission can make a reinstatement order against a related company if it deems it just to do so.
. The matters to which the Court or Commission will have regard are:
. the extent to which reinstatement of the employee by the direct employer is impractical because the employer is in receivership or is in the course of being wound up;
. the extent to which the related company took part in the management of the direct employer;
. the extent to which the circumstances that gave rise to the receivership or to the winding up of the direct employer are attributable to the actions of the related company; and
. any other relevant matters.
The Court or Commission will also have an associated power to make any other orders that are necessary to give practical effect to the reinstatement order.

In the Patrick's situation, this provision would have permitted the Court to make an order reinstating the sacked employees to other companies in the Patrick group. The various requirements would have been easily satisfied because:
. reinstatement to the Patrick labour hire companies would be impractical because those companies were in receivership;
. clearly the Patrick group played a substantial part in the management of the Patrick employing companies;

. the circumstances which gave rise to the receivership of the Patrick employing companies were clearly attributable to the actions of the Patrick group—it was they who orchestrated the corporate scam which lead to the companies being in receivership.
This provision will therefore ensure that companies can not use the Patrick corporate scam to leave their workers without any effective remedy against unfair and unlawful termination.
Secondly, section 178A of the bill allows employees to claim accrued legal entitlements against a related company of their direct employer in certain circumstances.
The related company will be liable for the payment of any legal entitlements of unpaid employees in the following circumstances:
. the related company has entered into a contract for the carrying out of work for or on its behalf the direct employer, including a contract or arrangement to hire labour from the employer;
. the direct employer has contracted to undertake work for or on behalf of the related company, including the provision of labour services to the related company;
. the work is carried out in connection with a business undertaking of the related company;
. the relevant employees are, or at the time of the non payment were, subject to an award, an order of the Commission, a certified agreement or an Australian workplace agreement.
It is worth noting that these provisions are based on the successful precedent of section 127 of the NSW Industrial Relations Act 1996.

In the Patrick's situation, this provision would make the Patrick group of companies liable for the accrued legal entitlements of the employees of the Patrick employing companies. The requirements would have been easily satisfied:
. the Patrick group and the Patrick employing companies entered into contracts for the hire of labour from those companies to the group;
. the work under the contracts was carried out in connection with the stevedoring undertaking of the group;
. the employees were, at the time of non-payment, subject to an award and a certified agreement.

So this provision ensures that, in future, company groups will not be able to escape liability for accrued legal entitlements by leaving employees employed by $2 companies that go into receivership. In these circumstances, the group of companies will be liable for payment.
The two amendments to the Corporations Act are as follows.

First, Division 6A of the bill, provides that, where a company is in receivership, the Court can make an order requiring a related company to pay the debts of the other company, including debts owed to employees, like accrued entitlements.

This amendment is basically for the same purpose, and is substantially to the same effect as, the new section 178A of the Workplace Relations Act. It is included for abundant caution, to ensure that both acts recognise the liability of related companies for accrued legal entitlements of employees.
The requirements for liability of the related company in this case are also somewhat different.
The matters which the Court will take into account in determining whether to make an order are as follows:
. the extent to which the related company took part in the management of the employer;
. the conduct of the related company towards the creditors of the company generally and to the creditor to which the debt or liability relates—ie, the employees;
. the extent to which the circumstances that gave rise to the winding up of the employer are attributable to the actions of the related company; and
. any other relevant matters.
Again, this provision will give greater security to employees in relation to their accrued legal entitlements.

Secondly, amended section 1317HD of the Corporations Law, will give creditors the right to bring proceedings for the recovery of debts against directors of companies acting in contravention of the Corporations Law.
At present, only the company, usually the liquidator or receiver, has this right.
Under this provision, creditors such as employees will be given the right.

In the Patrick's case, it would mean that the employees of the Patrick companies, not just the receivers, would have the right to sue Chris Corrigan and the other Patrick directors for debts arising from breaches by them of the Corporations Law.

It is ironic, that while this government was scheming with Patricks to illegally sack workers and rushing in to provide $250 million in redundancy payments, it was publicly condemning the actions in Cobar. Yet, when the Cobar miners who have lost their jobs and their entitlements ask the government for a $9 million loan to fund their redundancies, no money was forthcoming. This is hypocrisy at its finest.
I noticed that the Prime Minister has finally realised that security is a vital issue to Australians, despite the Minister for Workplace Relations claiming it is not of great concern to workers.

No amount of promises or weasel words will enable the government to persuade the Australian people that their jobs are safe from this sort of scam. Only action will help redress the wrong this government has committed.
This action must start with supporting the Employment Security Bill 1998 which will protect workers from Patrick-style corporate scams.
The Prime Minister has thus far supported Patrick in the illegal sacking of its workforce.
The Prime Minister has shown the Australian people that the law is only binding on certain sections of the community, that is, unions.
The Prime Minister has shown himself to be a partisan participant in the attempt to deny Australian workers the protections afforded to them by law.
The Prime Minister now has an opportunity to show the Australian community that he is committed to job security by supporting this bill.
If this support is not forthcoming, the Australian people can safely assume that the Prime Minister's "Triple S" pledges actually mean: `security' guards, `security' dogs and `security' fences.

debate.para: Motion (by Senator Brown) proposed:

(a) views Indonesia's leadership succession as the beginning rather than the end of a process of change and reform needed to create political and economic stability based on the full participation of the Indonesian people and on respect for human rights;
(b) calls on the Indonesian Government to adopt Amnesty International's agenda for human rights reform, and in particular its call for:
(i) the immediate release of all political prisoners in Indonesia and East Timor,
(ii) a public commission of inquiry into recent killings and disappearances in Indonesia,
(iii) ensuring the independence of Komnas Ham, the Indonesian National Commission on Human Rights, to investigate cases of killing and disappearance and allow it to act on its findings,

(v) access for the international human rights organisations to Indonesia and East Timor; and
(c) calls on the Australian Government to:
(i) suspend its military assistance program until free and fair elections have been held, and
(ii) publicly support the work of Komnas Ham in Indonesia and provide support through technical assistance.

talk.start.para: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 1123, standing in my name for today, relating to the One Nation Party, be taken as a formal motion.
—Is there any objection to this motion being taken as formal? Formality is denied, Senator.
—Pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

speech.para: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Colston moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 1123.
It is necessary to look at notice of motion No. 1123 in detail to indicate the urgency of this matter. No. 1123 says:
That the Senate urges political parties and non-aligned candidates in Australia to:
(a) acknowledge that the alarmist and divisive rhetoric employed by members of the One Nation Party has damaged Australia's social fabric and its international reputation;

(b) not simply condemn but constructively campaign against the knee-jerk populism which passes for the policy platform of One Nation in order to reveal it for its inherent flaws and its inability to contribute intelligently to addressing the many issues of great concern which confront Australia today;

(c) demonstrate to those constituents to whom One Nation has some appeal that the simplistic and alienating rhetoric of One Nation is no substitute for substantive policy responses to the issues presently before the nation;

(d) stress to those same constituents that while diversification of party choice can foster a liberal democracy, the establishment of parties such as One Nation can only work against the national resolve required to address our society's ills;
(e) admonish any action to favour political expediency over political commonsense by considering preference deals with the One Nation Party; and
(f) place ONP candidates last on their recommended preferences in State and Federal elections.

In relation to that notice of motion, we currently have a state campaign being waged; it looks fairly certain that we will soon have a federal election campaign, and there will be other states which will follow with elections themselves. In those circumstances, it is necessary that we address these matters outlined in this notice of motion, and address them now rather than at some future date.

talk.start.para: —We in the government do not think urgency has been made out for this motion. There is an opportunity to debate matters of general business on a Thursday. The practice used to be that attempts to suspend standing orders in order to bring on general business notices of motion were a rarity. They have become commonplace. The consequence of that of course is that government business time is lost. I am not arguing the right of Senator Colston to raise a matter that is of concern to him, but I am suggesting that it should not take the place of other business of the Senate. Therefore he should have his opportunity to call it on, as a matter of general business, on a Thursday in the way in which business used to be done. I presume, consistent with that philosophy, that this opposition has an arrangement whereby Independents and minority parties are given a fair share of the occasions on Thursdays for such debate. We believe that is the appropriate time for it.

—The Labor Party, the opposition in the Senate, will oppose the suspension of standing orders. I would like to point out to you, Madam President, and to the Senate, that we consider this motion to be a case of one utterly discredited Queensland politician—that is, Senator Colston—trying to discredit another utterly discredited Queensland politician—that is, Pauline Hanson. As far as the members of the opposition in the Senate are concerned, we will have no part of this grubby and absurd political exercise.

speech.para: The truth of the matter is that Labor's record in relation to Pauline Hanson has been clear, principled and unwavering. It stands in stark contrast to what we have seen from the Liberal Party since Ms Hanson first became prominent in Australian politics. In relation to the issue of preferences, the Labor Party has categorically made its position absolutely clear. That is a position from which we have not wavered for a very long period of time.

In fact, as early as October 1996, when the inherent threats of One Nation to Australia's stable and multicultural society and economy were apparent, the National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, Gary Gray, stated on the Channel 9 Sunday program that we, the Australian Labor Party, would put One Nation last on our how-to-vote ticket. I might say, by the way, that so did Mr Andrew Robb, the then federal director of the Liberal Party. Remember that it was the Labor Party that sponsored, negotiated and supported a bipartisan motion in this parliament against racial intolerance, a motion which was in response to the national and international outrage over the member for Oxley, and we will have no part in this action taken in this chamber by someone as discredited as Senator Colston.

We consider Senator Colston's actions also to be unprincipled, reprehensible and venal and we are not going to see the Labor Party associated in any way with any move or any exercise in which he tries to attempt to grandstand and claw back some of his lost status, standing and image in the community. We will have no part of it, and of course we also know that events have superseded the rhetoric that is contained in Senator Colston's motion.

In the Queensland election, where the Liberal Party and the National Party are tying themselves in knots over the issue of preferences from the One Nation Party, Labor's position has been clear for a very long period of time. It is a principled position. We will not resile from it, we have not resiled from it, and we will be absolutely consistent in that position. We do not need an individual of the standing of Senator Colston coming in here and telling the Labor Party or the parliament how we should approach these sorts of matters.

Our stand has been proper, it has been principled and it has been consistent. We will continue to stand up and provide the political leadership that is required in this nation on the issue of racism and on the issue of the rise of the One Nation Party. We remain the only major political party in this country that is willing to make that level of commitment in defence of our national cohesiveness and our international standing. Mr Acting Deputy President, I can assure you we will never support such a contemptible, low-life, despicable, political tactic from Senator Colston.

talk.start.para: —Firstly, let me state that the Greens were the first party to say that we will not give One Nation preferences—it will go last—and the Queensland Greens made that clear from the outset. But this is not about that debate: this is about the right of every senator to be able to function in this place. It is a matter of democracy. It is a matter of Senator Colston, for whom I hold no particular brief, being able to function here, while ever he is a legitimate member of this Senate, no more or no less than any other member. If we proscribe Senator Colston, send him to Coventry and cut off his right to speak in this place the same as everybody else can, where does that stop? It is a matter of democratic principle at stake here.

speech.para: The government says, `Senator Colston can go and ask the Labor Party to bring up this motion on Thursday.' Senator Hill knows that the Labor Party will not allow that to happen. The Labor leader, Senator Faulkner, says in effect, `We are not going to support this motion because of the person who is putting it forward'—forget the principle; forget the urgency with which people on this side of the House feel that One Nation should be tackled in Queensland.

talk.start.para: —I am not going to be lectured to by Colston.

—The Leader of the Labor Party in the Senate—who by the way has just voted down a motion on East Timor's independence and the freedom of its leader Gusmao—says he is not going to be dictated to by Senator Colston. This is not a matter of being dictated to; this is a matter of the right of every elected member of this Senate, while they remain in this Senate, to be able to bring forward motions, take part in debate and take part in votes as they will.

speech.para: Once we start to trammel the right of any member because we hold a grudge—as the Labor Party holds a deep and just now expressed grudge against its former member in Senator Colston—where does that stop? If this motion succeeds, it will be a low day in democratic principle for this chamber of the Australian Parliament. I know they will try to muddy the waters here; I know people will say, `If you get up and defend this, you are defending Senator Colston.'

talk.start.para: —Will you move the same motion tomorrow?
—The Labor Party intervenes and asks if I will move the same motion.
—Senator Brown, your remarks should be addressed through the chair.

—The fact is that the Labor Party, no less than the Greens or anybody else in this place, has had the ability to move this motion. The fact is that Senator Colston has moved it. The fact is that, if it were to go to a vote, then I would support it on behalf of Australian Greens, but that is not the principle at stake here. The principle at stake is the right of any member—no matter whose banner they stand behind—to move a motion in this place, have it debated and put to a vote the same as any other member.

speech.para: The Labor Party is saying, `We are not going to allow that to happen because we hold a grudge against a member.' I say again that, if we support that Labor Party tactic, where do we end up? Once you start to erode the right of elected members of parliament to function in the parliament, you are on the slippery slope and pulling the rug from under democracy and proper representation itself.

I stand by Senator Colston's right—the same as Senator Faulkner's right; the same as Senator Hill's right—to move a motion, have it debated and voted on in this place. I will not stand for the erosion of that right under this guise of political hate and political censorship which the Labor Party and the government in its own way have engaged in here today.

talk.start.para: —Senator Hill is correct when he says that this is a motion that should be debated, but it should be debated at the proper time, on general business day, and it behoves the opposition to allow Senator Colston time to debate it on the proper general business day. The case for urgency has not been made today.

speech.para: I am amazed that Senator Faulkner should speak about his party being a proper and principled one. You might tell me which party it was that put the Australians Against Further Immigration—that scandalous, shabby, smutty party of the Right—before the Liberal Party at the Lindsay by-election? Which party was that? The Australian Labor Party did that. It promoted and preferenced the Australians Against Further Immigration in front of the Liberal Party at the Lindsay by-election. You have the gall to get up here and say that you are the party of properness and principle. What absolute hypocrisy and humbug!

Some reference was made by Senator Faulkner to the Queensland state election and how principled and proper the Australian Labor Party is in its direction of preferences in that contest on 13 June. If I remember correctly, it was only this morning on the radio that the Australian Labor Party in Queensland said to One Nation supporters, `Look, because there is optional preferential voting in Queensland, don't you give your second preferences to anyone.' Because it is well shown from the polling that the One Nation voters are people who have previously voted for either the National Party or the Liberal Party, one would normally expect that their second preferences would have gone back where they were last time and that is what the polling has shown.

But the Labor Party with a huge bout of hypocrisy yet again says, `Direct your preferences to us by making sure your vote does not count', that is, `Don't direct a second preference. That will mean it is a vote against the coalition and a vote for the Australian Labor Party.'

Just today the Australian Labor Party in Queensland has asked, directed or told the One Nation voters and the One Nation candidate that they should give their preferences to the Australian Labor Party. It is hypocrisy and humbug for the Australian Labor Party to condemn Senator Colston in this way and his right to bring this matter forward.

talk.start.para: —Why should we give you a leg up?

—Senator Gibbs agrees with that. In the Queensland election you want to ask the One Nation people to give their second preferences to the Labor Party against the coalition. You are asking for their preferences in Queensland.
—Yes; rather than let you get in.
—You say, `Yes.' Can I take that interjection?
—Senator Macdonald, address your remarks through the chair.
—Hansard would have got that. Senator Gibbs agrees that the Labor Party in Queensland have asked One Nation for their preferences.
—She did not.

—Hansard will show it. It was shown to the world on the radio this morning that the Australian Labor Party wants the One Nation preferences and is going about campaigning for them in Queensland. Senator Faulkner spoke about how tremendous the Labor Party is against racism and how poor my party is. Can I ask Senator Faulkner: which party was it that got rid of the white Australia policy promoted by the Labor Party for decades?
—Gough Whitlam
—Tell me which party it was, Senator Carr.
—Which party is putting One Nation last on the how-to-vote cards?
—It is not the Australian Labor Party, Senator Faulkner. If you heard the news this morning, if you heard Senator Gibbs just now—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. You have pulled other people up for not addressing through the chair. I wonder whether you might do the same for Senator Ian Macdonald.
—I have given Senator Ian Macdonald two warnings on that point.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Mr Acting Deputy President, Senator Gibbs, a Labor senator from Queensland, has indicated that her party does want the One Nation preferences in Queensland—and the Hansard will show that quite clearly because the interjection was taken. But, whether Senator Gibbs says it or not, it is clear on the record for everybody to see that, just this morning in Queensland, the Australian Labor Party effectively was asking for One Nation preferences.

speech.para: As I was saying when I was interrupted by Senator Margetts, it was the Liberal-National Party coalition that got rid of the white Australia policy—a policy that had been made part of the political life of Australia by the Australian Labor Party. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In speaking to this question of whether or not this motion should be brought on for a vote, I note that the previous speaker, Senator Ian Macdonald, has indicated that a case for urgency has not been made out. I would address that topic, considering that it is part of what this debate is meant to be about.

speech.para: Despite what government speakers are saying, it is clear that this motion will not come on for debate in general business; it certainly will not come on for debate in general business this week, if at all.

talk.start.para: —Why not?

—This is the last week in which the Senate will be sitting before the holding of the Queensland election. Given the focus of this motion, and particularly its focus on the One Nation Party, this is something that is particularly relevant to my own state of Queensland. The outcome of the Queensland state election is very important for Queensland's future, just as will be its potential flow-on effects for the federal election, particularly again in terms of representation for some of the federal seats in Queensland.

speech.para: So this is an urgent matter. It is important that the Senate does have an opportunity during this week to express a view on this motion put forward by Senator Colston, because this will be the last time that all senators are able to be put on the record in relation to their views on the issues put forward.

In that regard—and one would have thought this would go without saying but, given the remarks made by the ALP, obviously it does need to be said—in voting and expressing a view on a motion, one should do so in relation to the actual wording of the motion. To try to avoid taking a position on a motion simply because there is dislike for its mover, I find, is disingenuous, to say the least, and inappropriate. The ALP have indicated that they support the motion's wording and, therefore, I believe they should allow themselves to be placed on the record in relation to the motion as it stands, rather than to try to dodge it because they do not like the person who has moved it.

I think the issue of preferences and the preference recommendations of all parties on the how-to-vote cards in the Queensland election will be crucial. I should place on the record that the Democrats long ago indicated that they will be placing One Nation last on all their how-to-vote cards. That decision was made by our state council many, many months ago at a state council meeting in Ipswich, by coincidence. That is something we have stayed solidly firm on since that time.

Because of the optional preferential system that operates in Queensland, it is important that all parties give a commitment not simply to try to ignore One Nation or take a non-committal stand on it, but that they actually commit themselves specifically to putting One Nation candidates last. The option is open there for all parties simply to have a how-to-vote card that shows a single first preference and leaves all the other options. In that circumstance, it provides an opportunity for a de facto first-past-the-post contest to eventuate.

In that circumstance, those areas, those few seats that have been given some focus as being ones where there is a high One Nation Party vote—and they are seats similar to those that in the past have pulled high votes for other extreme right wing parties, such as the Confederate Action Party and the Citizens Electoral Council which unfortunately do have some ongoing support base in Queensland—once again quite probably these will pull a reasonable vote for One Nation. If the circumstance is allowed to develop where a de facto first-past-the-post contest does occur, that will give those people a much greater chance than they have had in the past of gaining a seat in the Queensland parliament.

For those reasons, it is crucial that parties do not simply commit to not allocating preference towards One Nation but that they specifically commit to preference against One Nation and put One Nation last, as the Democrats have indicated they are going to do.

For that reason, it is important that all parties go on the record about this. We will see soon enough with the how-to-vote cards that are issued over the next few days in Queensland what will happen in that regard. But, if all parties were to do that, it would enable us all to finally focus on some policies in the Queensland election. Unfortunately, there has not been much of that to date because of the focus on the novelty of One Nation's performance.

The fact is that, if all other parties commit themselves to putting One Nation last, One Nation has no chance of winning a seat. That is why this is a crucial matter for the future of my state of Queensland. Also, it is potentially a future matter for Queensland because I am sure that all senators agree on how divisive and dangerous One Nation's policies are. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, this matter is so urgent that it was put off yesterday—which will give you an idea of the urgency of it. The fact is that preference decisions eventually will be decided by the various political machines around the country, both at a state and federal level.
—They won't; they're determined by the voter with a pencil in their hand.

—Of course. But at least concede that the recommendation as to allocation of preferences by a political party will be determined there and not in the Senate. Senator Faulkner is quite right to say that we have made our decision: we are going to put One Nation last in every federal electorate—the whole 148 next time, if they contest those—and we are going to put them last in the Senate.

speech.para: That is our position. We do not need to carry resolutions here today or anywhere else. We announced that a year ago, and we are going to stick with it. It is up to other political parties to explain their position and to justify their position in that regard. I was very pleased with the remarks by Senator Bartlett and some of the remarks by Senator Brown where they indicated that that is their position. I think that is a very appropriate position. I hope they acknowledge that our position is equally appropriate.

talk.start.para: —Are you going to do it in the state election as well?

—Of course we are going to do it in the state election, Sena tor. The great virtue of carrying these things by way of our national executive is that it is binding on all the constituent units of the Labor Party. So the answer is yes and yes. Senator Bartlett, when it comes to the Queensland—
—Senator Ray, please direct your remarks through the chair.

—Absolutely. I was about to inform Senator Bartlett that, in the question of Queensland Senate elections, should the now Independent Senator Colston run—and despite our rather diminished view of him—we will send him preferences ahead of One Nation. Nothing could demonstrate to anyone more clearly our commitment to putting One Nation last than sending preferences to Senator Colston or the Queensland First Party if it happens to run with him at the head of the ticket. We can give no clearer indication that we are willing to put the past behind us and prejudice behind us and do that particular thing. I am glad that I am not a Queensland elector because you would have had to steady the pen, but nevertheless that is the way our tickets will go.

speech.para: Points that have been made in this particular debate go to what formal motions are and what they are not and the direction that the Senate is taking. You only have to look back over the last hour to know that the Senate is starting to lose its way. These points were made in a different form and in a different way by Senator Harradine some weeks ago. I think we gave him sympathetic if not actual voting support on that occasion. Every device in the Senate, once it starts to be exploited, just steamrolls. We have seen it in the past with petitions and disallowance motions and everything. We are now getting to the stage where today something like eight or nine or 10 motions have been asked to be carried formally. I think there comes a point in time where the Senate is going to say, `We are not going to carry resolutions without debate.' We can also have the choice of what resolutions we want to debate. That is our democratic right. That is what we were elected to do: to determine which resolutions by way of ma jority that we want to debate, Senator Brown. We have rights too.

talk.start.para: —Just what I am warning you against.
—Just because we are in a major party does not mean that we do not have rights.
—Just what I am warning you against.

—We have a right occasionally to say, `Will the Senate be distracted on an exercise of moral rehabilitation of a discredited Senator?' We say no. We are not going to be distracted by that. We are not going to have Senator Colston sneak around and try to find every sympathetic resolution he can find to try to resurrect his discredited career, especially when on the principle and the subject matter our views are clearly known and clearly expressed. We are bound by party discipline on this. We are going to put One Nation last; end of story. (Time expired)

—One wonders why there is heat in this debate. What we are debating right here and now is whether the motion moved by Senator Colston for the suspension of standing orders ought to apply to his notice of motion. Does anyone in this chamber believe that his notice of motion is not to do with a major question of public policy?
—Yes, absolutely. It is just a sleazy tactic by a sleazy senator.
—I believe that is out of order.
—No, it is in order.
—I believe that is out of order, and I ask you to rule it out of order, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—It is out of order, Senator Ray. I ask you to withdraw that please.
—I comply.
—I will not get distracted by that sort of remark that is not fitting for this place.

—Yes, I did ask the question. You apparently do not believe—
