There is, for reasons I cannot go into now, some issue as to whether or not funding will continue to that particular undertaking in Angola. I take this opportunity to urge Australia and Australia's government to see to it that that undertaking is kept going because it does provide much needed aid to women and children, and men as well. Anyone who is injured is entitled to sympathy and to an artificial leg, I would say. Those people are entitled to the legs that they would otherwise be denied were funding withdrawn. Australia is not the only country that people can look to for funding, but certainly we are a compassionate nation and we need to look to that.

In Mozambique I witnessed the blowing up of a couple of mines around a particular village. I was with other Australians at the time. The crew that undertook the clearing of mines in Mozambique were trained by the Australian Army. This is a proper time to acknowledge the work that the Australian Army does overseas in actions such as this where its personnel clear mines. It is a task that needs a lot of patience, training and concentration. Those elements have been put into the area by the Australian Army. They were directly in charge at one stage; now they are at the point where they have become advisers. I think that is something to be proud of. Major Peter McIntosh was on duty at the time I was there and I would like to acknowledge the great service he has given to Mozambique and to Australia. I acknowledge not only him but those who went before him and those who will come after him. It is a noble task.

Let me end this way, Madam Acting Deputy President: if you do get the chance, do urge the government to keep the undertaking going in Angola. Secondly, if you ever go to Mozambique go and see the mine clearing and make sure you give the Army personnel there great credit. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —In the adjournment debate this evening I wish to comment on the current debacle in Sydney over the East Circular Quay development. The erection of a 15-storey building that obscures a view of the Opera House from almost every part of the city is an absolute outrage. Not surprisingly, it has prompted a public outcry. A public meeting last week attracted 1,500 protesters, including the playwright David Williamson, scientist Dr Tim Flannery and broadcaster Margaret Throsby. The meeting heard estimates of the cost to get the site back ranging from $250 million to Premier Bob Carr's touted figure of $700 million.
—He is trying to balance his budget.

—Yes, he is trying to balance his budget. Regardless of the cost, the meeting was unanimous in its decision that the building, dubbed the `toaster', has to go and it has the support of international figures such as Robert Hughes and the architect of the Sydney Opera House, Joern Utzon.

speech.para: The depth of feeling locally, nationally and internationally means action must be taken. East Circular Quay is a site of great significance to Australians, as it is home for the building which many regard as our national icon and symbol, the Opera House. It also incorporates other Sydney landmarks: the harbour, the quay and the botanic gardens. Sydneysiders have great pride in the city, and they will not allow this building to ruin its appearance and its reputation. At the moment, arriving at a solution to removing the `toaster' poses great difficulty, as the whole issue—perhaps appropriately, given the site—has become something of an operatic event. The debate must be allowed to return to sensible levels of dialogue; emotion must be contained.

The role of the New South Wales Labor government in the fiasco is to be condemned, as is Premier Bob Carr's attempted sidestep to avoid tackling the issue and taking any blame. The fact of the matter is that it was Bob Carr who signed the approval for this building. This was 10 years ago, when he was the New South Wales minister for planning. Not only did he approve the development, he approved it to be 20 storeys high. The present building is 15 storeys high so, if Mr Carr had his way, it would be a third higher than it is now.

His approval has allowed a building that blocks out a view of the Opera House from most parts of the city. What great vision this man had, and has, for his state. He signed on the dotted line to allow a building which overshadows the Opera House. His actions have turned what was envisaged as an area for the people into a high-rise accommodation tower which only the very wealthy can afford. Mr Carr's signature has allowed an elitist tower, owned and developed by overseas interests, to spoil an unparalleled icon of our built heritage.

Even as minister for planning, Bob Carr exhibited the traits which are all too apparent now: lack of vision, lack of leadership and lack of commitment to the people of New South Wales. Now that the project to which he gave the nod has spun out of control, guess what? He is appealing to the federal government to bail him out. Based on press reports, there are indications that a solution could be brokered with the building's owners, Hong Kong Shanghai Hotels. Pressed about this, Mr Carr showed how diminished is his own party's confidence in him. Mr Carr mentioned a figure of $700 million being needed to buy the site back from its owners. Perhaps his own government does not keep him informed because it now emerges that Hong Kong Shanghai Hotels held private talks with the New South Wales government as recently as last year, at which they reportedly said that they would vacate the site for something in the order of $250 million.

The public meeting in Sydney heard that the Save East Circular Quay Committee had received word from an intermediary for the developer that it was prepared to sell the site for $300 million. The total value of the development has been put at $600 million. One thing that must be avoided is a Dutch auction with the owners to buy the site back. Very detailed examination must be made of the true value of the undertaking to the owners. In October last year the site was valued at $85.8 million by the Valuer-General. The fact that only 22 of the 237 apartments in this gross complex have been sold—and all of those before 1996—indicates that the project is something of a commercial dud. Obviously, at prices starting from $700,000 for a one-bedroom apartment to $5.5 million for a sub-penthouse, the owners have priced themselves out of the market and this may be behind their willingness to vacate.

Mr Carr and his government have consistently failed to listen to the people of Sydney on this matter and have only taken the cotton wool out of their ears in recent weeks. In the face of continuing protest—local, national and international—Mr Carr, using his $700 million figure, tried to insist that the building was too expensive to buy back and that the whole thing was just beyond his government to fix. Once again, he failed to recognise the values and pride Sydney people have for their city. They will not just turn away from what they regard as a travesty which was foisted upon them against their will.

They fought on and, only hours before the protest rally, it was learnt that the Hong Kong Shanghai Hotels had expressed a willingness to quit the site for something in the order now of $300 million. Having been caught out on the figures, Mr Carr has the unmitigated hide to turn to the federal government to come up with the readies to get the site back. Mr Carr's ineptitude in this matter has meant that the obstacles to resolving the problem have not been addressed.

A land swap might simply move the problem, not solve it. In the past, there has been justifiably strong resistance to the notion of swapping land next to the Opera House in return for land elsewhere, on the proviso that permission would be granted to exceed height restrictions in other locations. Given Bob Carr's previous penchant for a 20-storey building, such a scenario is a frightening possibility.

The government has control of much harbour and foreshore land and it must be stopped from doing any deal which compromises these sites. But there is no doubt that the East Circular Quay apartment building is out of character with the site, with the city and with the wishes of the people, so the problem cannot be left unresolved. The critical question is: where would the funds come from to get rid of it? One suggestion which seemed to have some merit was to start a new lottery to help raise some of the money needed. After all, this was how the Opera House was funded, so it would be appropriate to at least help return East Circular Quay to the way it was envisaged through similar means. But the New South Wales government has poured cold water on that idea.

Another suggestion was a one-off fee in New South Wales. Raising $300 million would represent a cost of $67 to each New South Wales resident over the age of 20. This would be in keeping with the desires of the people after a recent Bulletin poll showed people were overwhelmingly opposed to the idea of using taxpayers' money to solve the issue. However, Bob Carr has turned to the federal government and wants money from the Federation Fund to be used to solve the problem. Not one solution has come forward from Bob Carr on his own account. Bob Carr obviously did not confer with his federal Labor Party colleagues on that one.
The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, has gone on record saying:
There are many priorities confronting that Federation Fund and I'm not sure that would necessarily be the highest.

Effectively he has told Bob Carr to abandon the idea. For once I agree with Mr Beazley. The Federation Fund was, however, not established to help remedy Mr Carr's colossal errors of bad judgment. The billion dollar fund was set up in the 1997-98 budget to fund projects of national significance as part of the activities to celebrate this nation's centenary of Federation. Mr Howard made it very clear the funds belonged to everyone. Announcing the plan, he said:

Everybody will be treated equally because the centenary of Federation does not belong to one or other side of politics. It belongs to all Australians and this is a practical demonstration of that commitment.
Giving money to Bob Carr hardly fits that scenario.

The Federation Fund projects are ones of major cultural, economic and social significance. As part of Mr Carr's logic, he claims the coalition government is not giving enough money to New South Wales and he has conveniently ignored the fact that the Corowa bridge on the New South Wales-Victorian border is getting $12 million and that there is funding for the Opera House of $32 million and other money for the cathedral refurbishments and other projects.

Mr Carr ignores, in relation to the Federation Fund, that it is up to state governments to develop and to submit proposals for funding of major projects that would have the support of all Australians. Bob Carr has to find his own way to clean up the mess that he allowed to be created at East Circular Quay.

talk.start.para: —This evening I want to document the frustrations of one of my constituents who has been trying to make the adjustment from CES to working with Centrelink and Employment National. I am not going to make any comments myself. I am just going to use the documents that have been sent to me, because I think they clearly illustrate the enormous problems we have with these changes. This gentleman writes that on 9 September 1997 he was registered with DSS and CES and got casual work for eleven weeks around Christmas. He states:

speech.para: April 1998
Getting worried and financially desperate.
I am sorry that some members of the government on the other side seem to think it is amusing. I do not think you will as I go further. He continues:
But the big glossy ads for the new Employment National give me hope, assistance, training, case management.

Read in the Innisfail Advocate that the CES staff of 13 will be replaced by an Employment National staff of ONE serving the area from Cardwell to Babinda. A bit disconcerting but those glossy ads restore my faith.
April 17 1998
Put in my fortnightly form at Centrelink and ask if I have to do anything for the new system. No, I'm told, your registered on the computer. Too easy, such efficiency, I can hardly believe it.

D Day! I try to find the Employment National Office no one knows where it is. The CES is closed. I spend the afternoon ringing to find out something. Centrelink . . . is engaged as usual cant get through Emp. National . . . and . . . at last a . . . human voice but they cant help me they've never heard of Innisfail.
I presume it is a central telephone number.
They will get someone to ring me back.
Someone from Employment National—

rings me from Townsville he gives me the old CES number and address then he gives me a Cairns number—I have to pay STD—turns out to be the old CES. He senses my desperation I sense his. He will get back to me as soon as he can.

I've somehow been given the number of Jobs Australia Innisfail . . . they apparently are the old Skilshare and are also contracted. They tell me I need a Centrelink Job Search No. and they'll help me. Living 10 miles out of town these visits are not easy. I go to Centrelink and ask for a Job Search No. The staffer looks surprised that I've found out about the secret numbers and reluctantly and with difficulty because the computers are not working properly gives me my number. At last, off I go to Jobs Australia, alias Innisfail Job Centre and their computer isnt working properly but they take my details and will get back to me once I'm linked.
I read in today's Innisfail Advocate that Emp. Nat. will be opening tomorrow in a small shopping centre in town.
I still havent heard from Jobs Aust. I ring and I'm told I am linked but there are only 4 jobs, none for me, sorry they forgot to ring me.

I come to town and to the new Emp. Nat. office. The phones and comps havent been connected yet but the operator . . . seems to know something. As a six to twelve month unemployed I'd be categorised as flex 2 and therefore jobs Australia would look after me. Emp Nat is contracted for flex 1 and 3. Centrelink should have categorised me and referred me!

I go home and ring Centrelink . . . its engaged then eventually I get an extensive spiel about things that have nothing to do with me until I'm told to wait for up to three minutes for an operator after 5 more three minutes I give up and ring complaints. I speak to—
someone—

who takes my concerns tells me shell fax them to Innisfail and Ill get a call within 3 hours. After 4 hours I ring her back shes surprised and says she will ring Innisfail and some one will contact me within the hour.

The Innisfail Centrelink manager . . . rings me and seems helpful and concerned about my situation she cant help me now cos the computer isnt working properly but she will find out and have everything by Monday.
It goes on:
The Centrelink manager—

doesnt seem quite so accommodating this morning she hasn't had time to find anything. She checks the computer which isnt working properly and gives me a form to fill in which will allow them to assess and categorise me she doesnt know why I hadn't been given this form earlier. There are teething problems. Funny cos I new about these changes months ago why didn't they?
D Day+1? I take my form in and I'm sure its the same info I gave in Sept 97. I wait 30 min to see an operator—
she—

takes my form and tells me I havent filled it out properly I show her that I have in fact. She doesnt want to process it and I suggest that it is the same info I gave in Sept. No she says, I'm sure says I, well its in a different format says she. Well I want to know what category I am and what assistance I can get. The computers not working properly anyway it will take 2 to 3 weeks for your case to be referred to Jobs Aust or Emp Nat.

I DONT BELIEVE IT I'VE BEEN CONNED. Why wasn't all this done before I've been wasting time for two weeks and now you say I have to wait 2-3 weeks more. It doesn't matter she says the training doesnt start till June 15 anyway. BUT there are only 10 funded places.

At this point, the constituent rang my office. Senators might say that this is just one example and that perhaps it is a case of the individual being unfortunate or not being able to access the right course for gaining assistance. But I am receiving—as are many of my colleagues in this place and in the other place—these kinds of complaints daily on the telephone. We also receive other letters.
I have a letter from a constituent in Bowen. Again, time will not allow me to detail it all but I will give you the flavour of it. It states:
At Home
Telephone call No. 1—To enquire when these employment services would be available. The department's officer's reply was `You know as much as I do.'
Call No 2. C.E.S Ayr—`No idea.'
Call No 3. C.E.S NSW—`No idea.'
Call No 4. The officer suggested we call 013 for the number of Employment National.
Call No 5. Employment National—Consultant to return our call.
Call No 6. Office of De Anne Kelly, M.P., federal member for Dawson, they would look into this matter and get back to us.
Reply from call No. 5—Employment National.
The consultant from E.N. advised that the available facilities were located at the office of Northern Employment and Training Organisation (NEATO) which has been established in Bowen for some time.
Reply from call No. 6—De Anne Kelly's office advised us to call NEATO.
Telephone call No. 7—Contacted NEATO and they advised that they would be available to see us on Tuesday—anytime.
Light at the end of the tunnel???

And so the letter goes on. An interview was then held but they advised my constituent that they were a private employment service and that they covered only the area from Ayr to Cannonvale, and my constituent does not live in that particular area.

If this were not so serious, this attempt at replacing the very good service that we had through the CES would be a joke. People are phoning and they are being given the runaround. There is nothing there for them. I hope that the minister on duty will take these concerns to the minister responsible because, as a Queenslander, he must surely be receiving as many complaints as I am. I understand that just as many complaints about the failure of the new system are being received throughout Australia.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to report to the Senate on the events of the last couple of days at Jabiluka and on my visit there last month. Before I get to that subject, I must say that Senator Coonan's message regarding the Opera House could just as easily have been said about Jabiluka. The international condemnation and community concern that she talked about happen when you put a uranium mine slap-bang in the middle of a world heritage area. I also entreat her to add her voice to the call for the Sydney Opera House to be nominated for world heritage—this is something that Senator Hill has been most reluctant to pursue since coming to office.

speech.para: But on the subject of Jabiluka, last week the Northern Territory police, along with the Darwin based tactical response team, moved onto the scene of the new uranium mine at Jabiluka. They gave the peaceful protesters there 24 hours to clear the blockade site and told them that they would be arrested, that their materials would be confiscated, and that road access to the site would be cleared for heavy duty construction works. The police and the tactical response group made it very clear that there would be a mass assault on those peaceful protesters.

Eighteen people were arrested on Tuesday of last week, including the Mirra senior traditional owner, Yvonne Margarula. She was arrested for being on the lease site, which is, of course, her own land. That very same day we saw protests in eight different countries around the world. Yesterday there was a pre-dawn raid at the site. The police arrived before the protesters had a chance to chain themselves to the blockade and there were a further nine arrests before 7.15 in the morning.

The police moved in with six police cars to block the road between Magela Creek and Jabiluka, and they stopped the protesters' vehicles attempting to go through by using the pretence of checking for defects. The protest will go on. There are many people still prepared to go to Jabiluka. These are the people who are carrying the flag for the majority of Australians and who do not want this country taking part in this deadly nuclear cycle.

When I was in Jabiluka a few weeks ago, the situation then was that the Northern Land Council had agreed to allow Energy Resources of Australia, the mining company, to proceed with the project in return for the sorts of promises that were made when the nearby Ranger mine began—promises which, by and large, have not been to the benefit of the local indigenous people and particularly not to the Mirra people.

ERA's announcement came with the advice that its consultation with Aboriginal people was complete but, of course, the question is: what Aboriginal people? The traditional owners were identified by Mr Justice Toohey in 1982 as the Mirra people. He said that the `Mirra are a local descent group who have common spiritual affiliations to sites on the land that place the group under a primary spiritual responsibility for the sites and the land.'

The Mirra people have held fast to their refusal to have a mine on their land. But the decision has been made on their behalf and not by them. It is also fair to say that ERA has attempted to render the Mirra invisible with the language in its publicity that engages in post-Mabo analogies of terra nullius.

Clearly, the Mirra people are hampered in their fight by the fact that they live in a place far removed from the central business districts of the eastern seaboard which, of course, are where most of the mining industry cheer squad reside—that is, the finance managers, the major banks such as the National, the ANZ and Westpac, and of course the mining company publicity machines. The latter are helped along by some $333 million of government subsidies to the industry over a five-year period.
One of the Mirra people asked me to convey this message to the Senate:

Please ask them to think of our children, our children's children, our children's grandchildren; to imagine a world with healthy humans on it for another 60,000 years . . . And ask them to consider that no one is perfect, mistakes will always happen, and that we can't afford to play with such incredibly destructive technology . . . to remember Hiroshima/Nagasaki, Chernobyl . . . and the many other disasters whose repercussions we are already living with and can never take back.
Very few politicians have been up to see what it is that is being earmarked for destruction. Unfortunately, this trickle is not threatening to become any sort of steady flow either.

It was my first visit to Kakadu, and I must say that I was overwhelmed with the extraordinary beauty of the place—the vast green wetlands, framed by ancient rocky escarpments; diverse forests of paperbark, palm and sheoak. It is a place which is teeming with wildlife, particularly birds. Termite mounds, for instance, two metres high are an attraction to the many tourists who flow through the area. I saw places where barramundi leap out of very clear streams and others where crocodiles lie in wait. You can look at this place and say it is untouched by European-Australian endeavours.

But at the same time the signs of Aboriginal culture are everywhere to see. I was taken to Ubirr, which is very close to the Jabiluka mining lease. This is a place to which overseas visitors flock in order to look at rock paintings which are thousands of years old. European and Asian tourists whom I saw while I was there were both alarmed and puzzled that anyone would want to set up a mine in this world heritage area. After they found out it was a uranium mine, they were even more incredulous—and I spoke with visitors who had decided to stay on to join the blockade.

I saw a group of houses alongside a river into which sometime earlier the effluent from the Ranger tailings dam had been released. A 35-year-old woman from this area had died a week previously. I was told that people who live in and around Jabiluka do not live much beyond the age of 40. People in this area use bore water instead of collecting rainwater from their rooftops; the reason is that the radon in the air is very dangerous. Jabiluka and the township of Jabiru may be very beautiful, but they are also very deadly places in which to live.

Most visitors do not get to see where Aboriginal people in this area actually live. The vast wealth which is dug from the ground has not brought many benefits to the Mirra people or other Aboriginal groups in the area. I saw a typical house; it was a small enclosure that looked much more like a chicken coop than a house in which you would put people. Nevertheless, these houses are crowded, and this is one of the reasons why scabies affects 90 per cent of the children in this community. Scabies is a Third World disease which has been eliminated from most places on the planet—but not here in Australia. And, of course, it is a disease which has long-term effects on these young bodies.

Jobs in the mine have largely gone to outsiders. The small amount of revenue from the mine flows on to ATSIC, to the land council, to tourism projects, and to fund services which we here in Canberra or Melbourne take for granted as being government services.

A few weeks ago wearing, I must say, a very small moral fig leaf, Minister Downer recalled our ambassador to India in protest at that country's nuclear tests. Australia however, I must say, is complicit in this lethal economy. The boundaries between the peace ful use of uranium and the market that eventually produces nuclear weapons are, indeed, porous. Let us remember that the Australian government cannot guarantee that no uranium finds its way into weapons manufacture.

The mismanaged nuclear industry has been propped up with the collusion of governments and banks. An accident occurring at Dounreay a couple of weeks ago is the latest in a long line of disasters in the uranium business. In the meantime, safe and renewable alternatives, such as wind and solar energy, gain a toehold ever so slowly.

I do not think we can rely on our present leaders to engage in ideas of responsibility to the planet and to the people in other countries on this issue. For instance, a couple of weeks ago, the submission by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to the Senate Economics Committee argued that Australia would fall behind in its role in international nuclear policy if the proposed new reactor at Lucas Heights did not go ahead.

This logic says that, by consolidating our status as players in this deadly industry, Australia will somehow do a better job of ensuring safety standards at plants in Asia and in negotiating on nuclear non-proliferation issues. It seems that we need more nuclear prowess in order to stop other countries using theirs—a little like the justification India has come up with to defend its own nuclear tests.

It is remarkable then that, in this political climate, hundreds of dedicated Australians have travelled to Jabiluka to lend their support to the blockade, and we are not talking about a quick trip here. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to address an area of great interest in that part of Sydney in which I work, the area of Greater Western Sydney—and that is the ongoing success of the University of Western Sydney. Since entering the Senate last year, I have been pleased to firstly establish, and then pursue, an ongoing relationship with the university, and I am constantly impressed with both the staff and students alike.

speech.para: UWS, as it is locally known, has a long history and very complex structure. It began operating in 1989 as a federated university based on three existing colleges of advanced education in Greater Western Sydney: the Nepean College of Advanced Education, the Hawkesbury Agriculture College and the Macarthur Institute of Higher Education.

It continues to operate in that way—as a federated university with three separate and distinct parts: Macarthur, Hawkesbury and Nepean. Each of those parts has its own culture, offers to the students its own courses, and services a different area of Greater Western Sydney. In fact, it is highly diverse even in terms of its geography. Between Macarthur, Hawkesbury and Nepean, there are seven individual sites across western Sydney. But it is UWS Nepean on which I wish to focus tonight.

Nepean is the largest of the three elements of UWS and is primarily based in Penrith on three sites: Kingswood, Werrington North and Werrington South. I was taken on a tour of the Nepean campuses very early on in my time in this place by my very proud colleague the member for Lindsay, Jackie Kelly. In addition to the Penrith sites is the latest inclusion of the Parramatta campus, to which I will return. UWS Nepean offers courses in eight faculties, ranging from business to science and technology, to performance, fine arts and design. With total enrolment at UWS Nepean alone in excess of 10,000 students, the university has proved its popularity with students from both the Greater Western Sydney region and beyond.

The Nepean site occupies land on which relics 20,000 years old have been found, with further evidence of occupation in the area indicating the presence of indigenous Australians as long ago as 47,000 years. This heritage is acknowledged and continued through the existence and operation of the university's respected Durali Aboriginal Centre. Nepean itself is situated in one of Australia's most historic urban regions. Penrith is one of the earliest townships established in the colony and was responsible for much of the supply of grains and foods to the colony. Similarly, honourable senators would know that Parra matta also has a rich heritage and is now one of the major centres of Sydney.

The newest campus of UWS Nepean is the Parramatta campus. At the beginning of this year, the faculties of business, law, nursing and health studies and some departments of the faculty of science and technology moved to the new Parramatta campus, which is one of particular historical significance. It is situated on the site of the former female orphanage, Australia's first purpose built orphanage, on the banks of the Parramatta River. The campus is home to Australia's oldest three-story building, thus ensuring that UWS Nepean has the honour of the nation's oldest university site; an honour I am sure the University of Sydney previously imagined was well within its keeping.

The foundation stone of the orphanage was laid in 1813 by Governor Lachlan Macquarie and the building was completed in 1818 and then began operation. The building had a very varied history, later being incorporated as part of Rydalmere Hospital before it was purchased by UWS Nepean from the state government in March 1995. All the redevelopment carried out by the university has been subject to a stringent heritage plan. The use of the orphanage is therefore extremely limited, but there is an aim of full restoration and use as a major heritage site and a public focus for research and education.

The area known as the Vernon precinct is also part of the campus. It consists of buildings constructed in the early 1900s which were also a part of Rydalmere Hospital. They now house the university's commerce faculty and will be used for teaching and for staff accommodation. Late last year I was pleased to be able to tour that site, which is close to my office, with Deputy Vice-Chancellor and UWS Nepean President, Professor Chris Duke; Pro Vice-Chancellor, Professor Harry Irwin; and Michael Charlton, the head of UWS public relations. Wandering around the construction areas even then showed me that the site is truly impressive and will be a very attractive educational facility when fully completed. Whilst there is ongoing work to be completed, the campus is already operational, with courses commencing this year. I know several students whose enthusiasm about their university and the new Parramatta campus is almost bordering on infectious.

UWS Nepean has been very successful at integrating with the community in which it is based. Already they have established a range of what they describe as cooperative programs which aim at involving local industry with the university. They have over 70 industry partners involved, and the programs are an enormous success. The first and perhaps one of the most successful is a student industry cooperative program called the cooperative education for enterprise development. It involves industry partners as diverse as the Australian Army, Hawker de Havilland, Barcode Solutions and the Sydney Church of England Grammar School.

The students are involved in a vast range of projects, with the 1996-97 graduates having participated in everything from creating an electronic bookshop to the development of a DNA based protocol for identification of native and introduced animals from hair samples. Incoming student projects are similarly as diverse, with projects such as a strategy development for youth and children's theatre in Parramatta and an evaluation of staff perceptions at Nepean Health.

The second cooperative program is a research program known as the Nepean summer research awards. It includes organisations such as the Olympic Coordination Authority, and those involved have described it as an invaluable two-way experience that provides us with fresh perspectives and solutions and also as a great opportunity for business to access enthusiastic and talented students. The final of the cooperative programs was introduced last year. The engineering summer placement program has benefited from the involvement of organisations such as Blacktown City Council and the Penrith Lakes Development Corporation, and it can only go upwards from there.

UWS also recently established the Western Sydney Research Institute, which is designed to coordinate research programs with regional industry and business groups. Aimed at ensuring integration between all three campuses—the Hawkesbury, the Nepean and the Macarthur—the institute will be involved in three main areas: environmental management, regional development and planning, and urban, social and cultural development. All these areas are particularly important to the healthy growth and wellbeing of western Sydney, with the potential for a direct and positive impact on regional, economic and industrial planning. Already the Western Sydney Research Institute is planning its first project: the construction of an enormous geographic information system for Greater Western Sydney. The university has committed $1 million to this project and is now looking to funding from regional partners involved.

I think anyone who has followed the progress of UWS since the late 1980s agrees that it has been an enormous success in giving more Australians access to higher education. Statistics from the UWS Nepean's student intake survey of last year indicated that nearly 70 per cent of students who completed the survey were first generation students. That is, neither of their parents had obtained a degree. The survey also indicated that nearly 40 per cent of respondents lived within 24 kilometres of the university. What is significant about these statistics for the community of Greater Western Sydney is that it is a clear indication that UWS is offering opportunities to students who may never have taken up those opportunities at existing facilities elsewhere in the Sydney metropolitan area. UWS is obviously servicing an appreciative education market.

One of the most gratifying aspects from these statistics relates to the number of UWS graduates who are not only finding work but also finding it in the Greater Western Sydney region. In 1993 the graduate success rate of finding work was well in excess of 80 per cent of students in full-time or part-time work, and over half of those in the local region. That is a tremendous boost not only to the individual students but also to their families and to our region.

Finally, I am also pleased to say that the University of Western Sydney has become the latest Australian university to appoint a female vice-chancellor. Professor Janice Reid, formerly the Pro Vice-Chancellor of the Queensland University of Technology, was appointed last year and took up her new posting earlier this year. UWS is an institution of crucial importance, not only as an important element of Australia's higher education system but also as one of the key providers of education and employment in western Sydney. All western Sydney residents, UWS staff, students and graduates are and should be justly proud of the progress the university has made in such a relatively short amount of time.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 6 April 1998:

question.para: With reference to the recent acceptance of a tender from Jandakot Airport Holdings Pty Ltd for the long-term lease of Jandakot Airport:

(1) Is the Minister aware that Jandakot Airport lies on the north-western corner of the Jandakot water mound, a ground water resource feeding water into Perth's public drinking water supply which is of vital importance in helping maintain adequate supplies for Perth's expanding population.

(2) Is the Minister aware that two-thirds of Jandakot Airport land is designated Jandakot water mound priority 1 or priority 2 underground water pollution control area (UWPCA) and comprises the most significant area of sand dunes still covered with original native flora south of the Swan River and close to the centre of Perth.

(3) Is the Minister aware that a company known as Soils Ain't Soils Pty Ltd, Perth's biggest soil blending company, has a major interest in Jandakot Airport Holdings Pty Ltd: if so, is the Minister concerned about the prospect of soil blending company having access to vast resources of sand in such an environmentally important and significant area.
(4) Have any discussions taken place with any of the tenderers for the airport lease, prior to the announcement of the successful tenderer, regarding sand deposits on Jandakot Airport land.
(5) Have any discussions taken place with the successful tenderer subsequent to the announcement of the outcome of the tender process.

(6) Was the Minister aware when deciding to accept the tender from Jandakot Airport Holdings Pty Ltd that the biggest of the three companies, Soils Ain't Soils Pty Ltd, was convicted in March 1997 of operating its soil blending operations without a permit from its Local Government authority, the City of Cockburn.

(7) Is the Minister also aware that Soils Ain't Soils Pty Ltd was convicted again in February 1998 for continuing to operate its soil blending activities without the required permit from the City of Cockburn, in defiance of instructions following the previous conviction, that it cease operations and that it vacate the site.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes. The Government is aware of the environmental sensitivity of Jandakot Airport, including the areas of significant native flora and the significance of the Jandakot water mound.

(3) Yes, Soils Ain't Soils has a major interest in Jandakot Airport Holdings. However, under the proposed lease for the Airport the Commonwealth retains all rights to all mineral deposits. This point has been acknowledged by Jandakot Airport Holdings.
(4) Yes, in discussions with all Jandakot Airport bidders, advice was provided that under the lease agreement the Commonwealth will continue to retain rights to all mineral deposits.

(5) The Department of Transport and Regional Development will be undertaking detailed discussions on the regulatory requirements with all Phase 2 airport lessees in the transition period, prior to completion of the sale process by June 1998.

(6) Yes. The Commonwealth undertook probity checks of all bidders as part of the bid assessment. Post-lease the airport will operate under very stringent environmental and planning controls. On the day of transfer to the new owners the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986 will cease to have jurisdiction over the operation of Jandakot airport and the Commonwealth Airports Act 1996 (the Act) and associated Airports (Environment Protec tion) Regulations (the regulations) will come into effect.

The Commonwealth will retain regulatory control over land use planning, environment and building control at Jandakot airport through both the Act and the regulations. The Act and regulations provide a comprehensive and holistic environmental management regime in relation to air, water and land pollution, indigenous and heritage sites management and noise emissions.

An integral component of the environmental protection regime at Jandakot airport is the require ment for new Airport Lessee Companies to develop and implement environment strategies. These must be in place within 12 months of a new airport operator taking over a leased Federal airport, and cover a five year period.

Part 6 of the Act, and part 3 of the regulations set out the requirements of Airport Lessee Companies in relation to their environment strategies. In their environment strategy the Airport Lessee Company must identify objectives for environmental management of the airport, areas which are environmentally significant and possible sources of environmental impacts. In addition, the Airport Lessee Company is required to address any relevant recommendation of a body established in the State in which the airport is located, having responsibilities in relation to conservation of biota, habitat, heritage or kindred matters. Further, the strategy must be available for public comment for a period of 90 days prior to submission to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. The Airport Lessee Company must document and address in its strategy comments received through this process.

The regulations also implement a monitoring regime at the airport which promotes prevention of water pollution on the airport site. The regulations identify the forms pollution might take, acceptable standards and imposes a duty of care on all operators at the airport to prevent pollution as far as is reasonable and practicable. To monitor this duty, and if required enforce the regulations, the Department of Transport and Regional Development will appoint an Airport Environment Officer at Jandakot who will be responsible for the day-to-day administration of environmental controls.

(7) Yes. As previously outlined post-lease the airport will operate under the most rigorous and stringent environmental regime ever put in place at Australia's airports. The Commonwealth will retain regulatory control over land use planning, environment and building control at Jandakot airport through the Airports Act 1996 and the Airport (Environment Protection) Regulations. The Act and regulations provide a comprehensive and holistic environmental management regime in relation to air, water and land pollution, indigenous and heritage sites management and noise emissions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 April, 1998:

question.para: (1) From what financial year will Tax Ruling 97/22 apply.

(2) Given that the mutuality principle affects the way in which clubs are assessed for tax exemptions: if membership fees are as low as $2 per annum: (a) does the Government recognise that this constitutes a loophole in the assessment of member income as tax exempt; and (b) what action does the Government propose in this regard.

(3) Given that the Australian Tax Office (ATO) cannot audit all clubs: what action does the ATO take to audit those clubs who may be using the `honour' system inappropriately for nominating their `non-member' income.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Taxation Ruling TR 97/22 provides information for clubs and associations that will enable them to determine if they satisfy the requirements for exemption from taxation. The Ruling operates for years both before and after its date of issue.

(2) (a) The mutuality principle does not determine if a club or association is exempt from taxation. Exemption from taxation is governed by Division 50 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 (the Act).

For a club or association to gain exemption under Division 50 of the Act, it must not be carried on for the profit or gain of its individual members and it must be established for purposes specified in the Division. As a member cannot personally share in the profits of such a club or association, the Government does not consider that a loophole exists in the taxation law. Rules and fees that apply to the obtaining of membership are matters for the club or association and are subject to laws other than the taxation law.

The mutuality principle can only have application to clubs and associations that are not exempt from tax under Division 50. The principle, which has long been a feature of the general law of England and Australia, recognises that the collective membership forms the legal entity that is a club or association and that the club or association can only be assessed on income received from non-members. Because of the principle, funds contributed by members to the club or association remain free of taxation because the contributions are no different than an individual taxpayer paying money to him or her self.
(b) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that no action is required at this time.

(3) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that the `visitor register', which is required to be kept by all clubs and associations admitting non-members to their premises, forms the main instrument for determining the level of income received from non-members and subject to taxation. The Commissioner stated that clubs and associations are subject to audit activity in the same way as classes of other taxpayers. They are responsible for lodging correct returns under self assessment arrangements. Where any tax return lodged by a club or association is found to be incorrect, appropriate penalties are imposed.
Several decided court cases challenging the exempt status of clubs or associations are indicative of the Commissioner's efforts in policing the tax requirements of this kind of instrument.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 8 April 1998:

question.para: (1) With reference to the Trade Practices Amendment (Fair Trading) Act 1998, passed by the Senate and the House of Representatives, and the definition of small business specified by that legislation: can an estimate be provided of how many of the nearly one million small businesses, when applying the Australian Bureau of Statistics definition, in Australia will be included in that `$1 million' definition.
(2) In what circumstances could any of those nearly one million small businesses be excluded

(3) With reference to the $1 million threshold test: (a) would a liquor store with 7 part-time, full-time and casual employees, purchasing $1.1 million worth of liquor from a single supplier, be covered by the legislation, with regard to that customer/supplier contract; (b) would a service station with 15 casual, part-time and full-time employees, purchasing $1.1 million worth of fuel from a single supplier, be covered by the legislation, with regard to that customer/supplier contract; (c) would a manufacturer with 99 casual, part-time and full-time employees, and a 5 year plus 5 year lease, amounting to $1.1 million in rental, be covered by the legislation, with regard to that landlord/tenant contract; and (d) would a computer franchisee with 20 casual, part-time and full-time employees, purchasing $200,000 of goods a year on a 6 year contract from the franchisor, be covered by the legislation with regard to that franchisee/franchisor contract.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business has

answer.para: provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:
(1) There is no data available on how many transactions might be caught by the legislation.

The Trade Practices Amendment (Fair Trading) Bill 1997 does not define a small business. Rather, subsections 51AC(1) and (2) limit access to the provision to persons other than listed public companies, and subsections 51AC(7) and (7A) limit the provision to transactions of $1 million or less.

Access to the provisions of the legislation is not limited to businesses that have a turnover of $1 million or less. Hence, a business with a range of contracts, for the supply or acquisition of goods or services of more than $1 million in total, may seek relief from unconscionable conduct in respect of a transaction priced at $1 million or less.
Also, the $1 million threshold for a transaction may be increased by regulation. I have undertaken to monitor the operation of the new legislation in this regard.

(2) Consistent with the response to question (1) above, a small business would be excluded from the provision in respect of a transaction valued at more than $1 million, or where the business is a listed public company.

Generally, when considering this issue a court would have regard to how contracts are constructed. A court would look into all the circumstances of a contract, including whether it may have been aggregated deliberately to avoid the provision, for example, if a landlord used its position of power over small business tenants to force them to aggregate leases that would not normally be aggregated.

(3) As stated in responses to previous parts of this question on notice, the specific circumstances of each transaction will need to be considered to determine whether a particular transaction falls within the gamut of the $1 million transaction threshold. Generally, except where a court may be required to examine whether a group of transactions has been aggregated to avoid the provision, the amount of a contract is easily understandable. In this context, consideration is likely to be given, among other things, to the nature of the goods or services in question, and the arrangements for ordering, delivering or providing, and paying for the goods and services.
